story:
Short Summary

My name is Dakotah and I have been practicing yoga for 5 years. I am a Buddhist, freelance writer, vegetarian, and musician. My yoga began at a local community college and has taken me as far away as China. Having been self-taught for the last several years, utilizing a number of valuable resources including /r/yoga, I have grown and excelled.

The time I spent traveling China taught me much about the world, providing me opportunity not only to experience Eastern culture but also offering interaction with travellers from all over the world. My horizons were never so broadened. I had the chance to pay my respect to the Leshan Buddha as well as to do yoga in temples and parks across the country.

I later lived in the Live Music Capitol of the World: Austin, Texas. During my time there, I, for the first time in my life, learned to make music. I have now been playing the ukulele for 2 years and owe much of my musical knowledge to my time in Austin, specifically at the Kerrville Folk Festival.

This summer, I intend to make a 6-week pilgrimage to further advance myself. The plan is to attend the Kerrville Folk Festival and then study yoga at the Asheville Yoga Center, earning a Yoga Alliance certification. This month and a half would allow me to develop my creative side and help pave my future.

By receiving this certificate, I will be able to teach yoga professionally. I have always dreamed of helping spread happiness to people and opening their eyes to yoga; this is my chance to make this a reality. Regardless of any perks and such, if this campaign helps me to succeed in my journey, I vow to teach a free class at least twice a month for a year to repay the cosmic energy.

What I Need & What You Get

What I'm asking for is help to pay for the actual 3-week Yoga Teacher Training class. By registering early, this entire immersion will cost only $1900 plus approximately $200 for books. The rest of the money I have requested will help pay for the air travel and lodging. I have some savings that will be helpful and can cover my basic expenses and some of the airfare but I can't afford to cover the entire cost of the class.

http://www.youryoga.com/ayc/teacher-training/200-hour/Total-Yoga-Immersion-Asheville.html

All the money raised will go directly to registration costs, travel bookings, transportation, and, if needed, feeding me on my travels. I will be able to live very cheaply while attending the folk festival but am not sure what to expect when I arrive in North Carolina.

Donating to this campaign means encouraging me to spread my message of love by bringing more yoga into people's lives. It will be helping me to find a career I can love by getting me to take the next step in my own life.

Perks

For $5, I will meditate on whatever you wish for a few minutes, sending positive energy in your direction. I can focus a mantra of power to you or thoughts of healing restoration to a sick friend or anything else.

For $11, I will consult my tarot deck on your life. I was a semi-professional reader on 6th Street when I lived in Austin and consider myself rather adept with the cards. Preferably, you will give me some background information on your life beforehand and I will email you a detailed synopsis but, if nothing is provided, I can give some general oversight with surprising accuracy. Ask about love, your career, your house and family, or even your travel plans

For $23, you will become a patron of my art. I have been writing as a hobby since I learned how to write and had my first poem published when I was 14. This perk allows you to choose up to ten topics for me to put into poetry, though I'd recommend picking a single theme for all 10 poems. These will not be hastily scrawled but well-thought out compositions.

The next three tiers, at $33, $77, and $255, are your chances to reap the benefits of my education. By supporting me while I become certified to teach yoga, you will be guaranteed one-on-one time with me, via Skype, to both receive guidance for your practice as well as pick my brain for useful yoga knowledge. I will be "fresh out of the academy" and able to offer perspective from my tutelage. Even if you're interested in pursuing a path teaching yoga yourself, this time could be spent familiarizing yourself with my experiences getting certified.

For $42, I will take the time to create a unique and creative video for you of me playing any two songs your ears desire on my ukulele. I'm no Van Halen or Frank Sinatra or Kamakawiwo'ole but I'll make it sound good. I can also change lyrics to make it more personal for you or dedicate the video to a particular person. Included will be separate audio tracks for each song to put on an mp3 player or what-have-you.

For $89. you commission a painting. You are free to pick anything you want it to be of though results will vary. Each painting will get scads of time put into it because, honestly, I'm a pretty slow and time-consuming painter, hence the price bracket. I will say, this one's a bit of a risk if you're not into art. If you are into art, though, this perk delivers.
story_txt:
Short Summary
My name is Dakotah and I have been practicing yoga for 5 years. I am a Buddhist, freelance writer, vegetarian, and musician. My yoga began at a local community college and has taken me as far away as China. Having been self-taught for the last several years, utilizing a number of valuable resources including /r/yoga, I have grown and excelled.
The time I spent traveling China taught me much about the world, providing me opportunity not only to experience Eastern culture but also offering interaction with travellers from all over the world. My horizons were never so broadened. I had the chance to pay my respect to the Leshan Buddha as well as to do yoga in temples and parks across the country.
I later lived in the Live Music Capitol of the World: Austin, Texas. During my time there, I, for the first time in my life, learned to make music. I have now been playing the ukulele for 2 years and owe much of my musical knowledge to my time in Austin, specifically at the Kerrville Folk Festival.
This summer, I intend to make a 6-week pilgrimage to further advance myself. The plan is to attend the Kerrville Folk Festival and then study yoga at the Asheville Yoga Center, earning a Yoga Alliance certification. This month and a half would allow me to develop my creative side and help pave my future.
By receiving this certificate, I will be able to teach yoga professionally. I have always dreamed of helping spread happiness to people and opening their eyes to yoga; this is my chance to make this a reality. Regardless of any perks and such, if this campaign helps me to succeed in my journey, I vow to teach a free class at least twice a month for a year to repay the cosmic energy.
What I Need & What You Get
What I'm asking for is help to pay for the actual 3-week Yoga Teacher Training class. By registering early, this entire immersion will cost only $1900 plus approximately $200 for books. The rest of the money I have requested will help pay for the air travel and lodging. I have some savings that will be helpful and can cover my basic expenses and some of the airfare but I can't afford to cover the entire cost of the class.
http://www.youryoga.com/ayc/teacher-training/200-hour/Total-Yoga-Immersion-Asheville.html
All the money raised will go directly to registration costs, travel bookings, transportation, and, if needed, feeding me on my travels. I will be able to live very cheaply while attending the folk festival but am not sure what to expect when I arrive in North Carolina.
Donating to this campaign means encouraging me to spread my message of love by bringing more yoga into people's lives. It will be helping me to find a career I can love by getting me to take the next step in my own life.
Perks
For $5, I will meditate on whatever you wish for a few minutes, sending positive energy in your direction. I can focus a mantra of power to you or thoughts of healing restoration to a sick friend or anything else.
For $11, I will consult my tarot deck on your life. I was a semi-professional reader on 6th Street when I lived in Austin and consider myself rather adept with the cards. Preferably, you will give me some background information on your life beforehand and I will email you a detailed synopsis but, if nothing is provided, I can give some general oversight with surprising accuracy. Ask about love, your career, your house and family, or even your travel plans
For $23, you will become a patron of my art. I have been writing as a hobby since I learned how to write and had my first poem published when I was 14. This perk allows you to choose up to ten topics for me to put into poetry, though I'd recommend picking a single theme for all 10 poems. These will not be hastily scrawled but well-thought out compositions.
The next three tiers, at $33, $77, and $255, are your chances to reap the benefits of my education. By supporting me while I become certified to teach yoga, you will be guaranteed one-on-one time with me, via Skype, to both receive guidance for your practice as well as pick my brain for useful yoga knowledge. I will be "fresh out of the academy" and able to offer perspective from my tutelage. Even if you're interested in pursuing a path teaching yoga yourself, this time could be spent familiarizing yourself with my experiences getting certified.
For $42, I will take the time to create a unique and creative video for you of me playing any two songs your ears desire on my ukulele. I'm no Van Halen or Frank Sinatra or Kamakawiwo'ole but I'll make it sound good. I can also change lyrics to make it more personal for you or dedicate the video to a particular person. Included will be separate audio tracks for each song to put on an mp3 player or what-have-you.
For $89. you commission a painting. You are free to pick anything you want it to be of though results will vary. Each painting will get scads of time put into it because, honestly, I'm a pretty slow and time-consuming painter, hence the price bracket. I will say, this one's a bit of a risk if you're not into art. If you are into art, though, this perk delivers.

story:
NEWS UPDATE: WE HAVE RECEIVED A PERSONAL DONATION OF $7,000!  So add that to the total and we are getting close... SO DONATE NOW! THANK YOU!


WHAT IS KISSIDUGU?  

Kissidugu - "a safe place" or "place of refuge" in the Kissi language of Guinea, West Africa.

And that is what your generous support will help create, a safe place; a school where youth of Guinea are being fed and educated in a sustainable and supportive environment.

We are The Kissidugu Foundation, a nonprofit organization. Our mission is to create sustainable and equitable opportunities for individuals and communities to access and promote cultural arts through music, dance, education and civic dialogue. The Foundation intends to inspire people of all colors, cultures, and backgrounds to connect to themselves, to one another, and to their community. Building the Kissidugu School of Music, Dance & Education in Guinea is the Foundation’s primary initiative.  It will provide education opportunities, sustainable employment and access to information and resources that would otherwise be unavailable.  The school will not only scholarship Guinean Youth but will also host international students for intensive study and cross-cultural exchange. We are so very passionate about this amazing project and excited to get you involved!

 

Kissidugu Dance & Drum Theatre was founded in 2004 after its first dance & drum conference, Camp Merveilles, in 2003.  Over the past 10 years, under the direction of West African master teacher-performer, Fara Tolno, Kissidugu Drum& Dance Theatre has been dedicated to bringing performance, art, and culture to communities across the United States and abroad. The Camp Merveilles conference has continued to be an annual event in Boulder, CO since 2003. Fara and staff have taught African dance and drumming to the faculty and students of schools from the elementary to university level;sharing dance and music through workshops in communities across the US and theatrical residencies with established dance companies.

Since receiving non-profit status, Camp Merveilles and the Kissidugu Dance and Drum Theatre have become projects of The Kissidugu Foundation and will continue with community outreach and education in the U.S.  Currently, The Kissidugu School of Music, Dance & Education is the foundation's number one focus.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $15,000 to purchase the land for the Kissidugu School of Dance, Music & Education. It is six acres of beautiful oceanfront property that is fertile and has areas of rich soil for growing food. This land will be home to the Kissidugu School of Dance, Music & Education, where dreams are made manifest and traditions are upheld. 

$15,000 for SIX ACRES!  Your dollar goes a LONG way!

We will be going to Guinea in December to finalize the land purchase with your generous support!

At this time, we are anxiously awaiting our "Letter of Determination" stating that we are a TAX EXEMPT non profit. Currently we are a non-profit in the state of Colorado, but are not yet tax exempt. We can retroactivate donations to be tax deductible ONCE we receive the letter, but until then we cannot. SOOO, knowing that many of you would probably like to receive a tax write off from your donations, we have decided to ask for A LOT of you to help us with small donations. IF you feel inspired to give more, and would like us to retroactivate the donation when the time comes, please let us know, we would be happy to provide that for you!

So that being said, you will receive small tokens of our deep appreciation, and become part of the creation and team of The Kissidugu School of Dance, Music & Education.  And most importantly you will know you are doing something great on the planet! 

 

 The Impact

The impact of the School in Guinea is huge.  Crops will be grown on site providing food and nourishment for the attendees as well as providing opportunities for surrounding villagers. In addition, the youth of Guinea have begun to lose the knowledge of their traditional music and dance. The school will serve as a living library of these traditions, giving the opportunity for Guinean Artists to pass down this ancestral knowledge. Not only will the School give Artists and Educators a place to teach, reside, and support their families, but will be a long term source of livelihood and valuable education for the youth and surrounding communities.

The School has four major focuses:  Food & Agriculture, Technology, Language, and Traditional Dance, Music and History. The school will start small with five resident teachers and 20 scholarshipped students from Guinea each year. In addition there will be an outreach program that trains educators and teachers from Guinea, so that they can take the skills and information learned and share it with their villages and towns.  In this way we create a ripple effect that can spread to other communities, reaching beyond our faculty and student body. The School will be sustained by the annual tuition received from international students and on-going agricultural endeavors.

We will use recycling, upcycling and alternative building methods; using materials such as tires and plastic bottles, therfore cleaning up surrounding areas as the school is implemented.  The intention of the Kissidugu School is to be a model of what is possible for other Guinean communities in the realms of sustainability.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please know that a little goes a long way!  Your five dollars WILL make a difference!  Spread this campaign to all of your friends and family, together we can do it!

You can also give in kind donations such as medicine/first aid, clothing, flashlights (solar/shakelights) and headlamps for the upcoming trip to Guinea.

 AND your skills and knowledge are valuable, if you would like to volunteer for the project, join us in Guinea, or help the Foundation in anyway, please let us know.

 Contact us at:  kissidugufoundation@gmail.com

 Website:  www.kissidugu.org

THANK YOU!

INUWAULI


Board Of Directors:

FARA TOLNO

MICHAL ANNA CARRILLO

ANGELA CARROLL

 

WE ARE TOGETHER!

WONTANARA!

story:
OUR STORY

Hi everyone!!!  Thank you for checking out our campaign!!!!

AfricanTennisNow.com was founded by Ashley Ndebele in 2013 to help promote tennis development in Africa.

Our mission is to bridge the gap between Africa and the rest of the tennis world.

There are so many young talented tennis players in Africa but the reality is that most of them can't afford to pursue their goals due to extreme lack of funds.  

Tennis is an expensive sport which requires constant travel to different tournaments but most young players don't have the resources.  Most of them can't even afford to own their own racquets, hence diminishing their chances of fulfilling their dreams.

Recently a frustrated seventeen-year-old rising tennis star from Zimbabwean  expressed her frustration. She is one of the many bright tennis players whose future is not so bright due to lack of financial support. She has so much potential, having won several premiere tournaments in Zimbabwe, but unfortunately she's had to turn down invitations for training in top tennis nations such as Burundi (the home of ITF East Africa Training Center), Egypt, Namibia, Kenya, and Spain because she can't afford to pay for travel costs. 

"I have always loved the sport and I am happy I have had the opportunity to play across the country and received recognition to play outside Zimbabwe. So far I have played at invitational tournaments in South Africa and Botswana while I missed out on several other tournaments where I believe I could have made a mark while improving my game.

"I have been selected to play in some of these tournaments but unfortunately failed to travel and sometimes I have other players replace me because I would have failed to travel due to financial constraints," said the seventeen-year-old.

It's really sad that the state of African tennis has declined tremendously while continents like Europe and Asia are flourishing.  In the 1990's, we had top players like the siblings Byron and Wayne Black from Zimbabwe, Wayne Ferreira and Amanda Coetzer from South Africa, and Hicham Arazi and Younes el-Aynaoui of Morocco competing at world-class tournaments.

Currently, the ATP (men's tour), WTA (women's tour), and the ITF (International Tennis Federation) Junior tours are dominated by Europeans.

ATP, WTA, & ITF RANKING STATS

  • Only 1 African player in the top 100; Kevin Anderson of South Africa is ranked #19
  • Only 2 African players in the top 200
  • Only 9 African players in the top 500
  • Only 25 African players in the top 1000 

  • Only 1 African player in the top 100; Chanelle Scheepers of South Africa ranked #70
  • Only 2 African players in the top 200
  • Only 3 African players in the top 500
  • Only 12 African players in the top 100

 Juniors - Boys

  • 1 African player vs 50 European players in the top 100
  • 19 African players vs 245 European players in the top 500

Juniors - Girls

  • 2 African players vs 59 European players in the top 100
  • 24 African players vs 249 European players in the top 500

THE PROJECT

The goal is to implement a digital platform that will connect financially struggling African tennis players, teams, and clubs with generous sponsors. The service will be free for users.

Online Fundraising: We will develop a simple fundraising tool for potential sponsors to contribute funds, tennis equipment, e.t.c. to players or teams.

Safe Communications: Centralized system for sponsors, coaches, parents and players (you have to be at least 18 years old to set up an account).

WHAT WE NEED

We need $12,000 to:

  • Develop the platform 
  • Test the platform
  • Market the platform
  • Indiegogo fees
  • Donor perks

THE IMPACT

Your support of this initiative will help bridge the gap between Africa and the rest of the world.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We could really use your help to spread the word to your friends and on social media networks by sharing the link of the campaign.

Cheers!!!

"No matter where you're from, your dreams are valid." - Lupita Nyon'go, Oscar Winner.

story:
This campaign is to provide funding for an art and music and dance school in India that also provides basic education to the children of impoverished families on the outskirts of the sacred city, Varanasi.  It was established in 2009.  (website)

The Wichi Art School, under the auspices of the Bhadra Kali Social Work and Development Association, has been providing primary school services to the children of "Harijans" or "Dalits" (once called "Untouchables" before untouchability and caste discrimination was banned in India).  The Wichi school focuses on art and music, especially tabla, the engaging traditional drums of India.  You can see an article about our early work HERE.

We also encourage our students to develop their minds through yoga, meditation and study, though we never force religion on any of our students.

The Wichi School has been funded by a few private individuals, but recently they have had to withdraw their support due to their own financial pressures.  At the same time, our school has been forced to look for a new location.  We now hope to buy a building to house our school.

In India, a few dollars can make for many rupees, but it will still take many dollars for us to resettle our school, and get the resources to take on more students (one of our most important goals).

Here is a video of one of our dance recitals:


Here is a video of a music class in progress:


Our school has been a success in so many ways.  Our kids read, write, do art, and all of them are getting prepared to enter the job market one day, armed with practical skills that will help them to find jobs in the exploding music and film industries.  Our greatest success may be that we have, in our own small way, broken through the barriers of caste and gender discrimination.

Please help us Wish For Wichi.

We would like to express our thanks to His Grace, Father +Nazarin, Presiding Bishop of The (San Francisco) Orthodox Catholic Synod of the Syro-Chaldean Rite (a registered Non-Profit Corporation) for his help and support in this effort.

story:
HELP MAKE THE DREAM COME TRUE

Contribute to the LEGACY OF A DREAM EDUCATION CAMPAIGN. Help bring teaching materials and the award winning film LEGACY OF A DREAM to schools (museums and libraries) across the country.  Made specifically for middle & high school students this 24-minute award winning documentary with its message of the "right to protest for right" tells the story of Martin Luther King's non-violent fight for social justice, human rights and the principle of equality for all.

We need you to make this campaign a success.  Your contribution will help make it possible for a new generation to learn about their history.  Nothing could be more important.  Join distributor Kino Lorber  and producer Richard Kaplan as they work to provide every middle and high school in the US with unlimited access to the documentary Legacy of a Dream and its teaching materials.  With your help we  can do this. Your contribution will make this happen.

Additional information about the film Legacy of a Dream

LEGACY OF A DREAM is an original documentary commissioned by the Martin Luther King, Jr. Center  for Non-Violent Social Change.  Produced and written by Richard Kaplan it chronicles the life and work of Martin Luther King, Jr.  It recounts Dr. King's fight for social justice, human rights and the principle of equality for all.  

Narrated by James Earl Jones, Legacy includes rare footage of King's speeches, protests, and arrests using contemporary film/newsreel and video/television footage to brilliantly convey the boiling indignation of an oppressed people and their movement to secure equal rights.



"...a piece of history of immense power" - LA Times

"Perhaps the most important film documentary ever made. "- The Philadelphia Bulletin

"When [young people] see this film, they will not only understand it, but will also experience it to the depths of their souls."-The Washington Daily News

LEGACY OF A DREAM is both a history of the non-violent, civil rights movement and a portrait of the movement's inspiring leader, Martin Luther King, Jr.  It is a cinematic national treasure that will provide students with first hand knowledge of their own history and allow them to witness King's crusade.  It will give a greater appreciation of the challenges he endured and the vast legacy he left behind.



TEACH A NEW GENERATION ABOUT THE RIGHT TO PROTEST FOR RIGHT!

Share the Legacy mission by contributing to IndieGoGo.

Learn more about Legacy of a Dream at http://alivemindcinema.com/legacy

LEGACY OF A DREAM is an original documentary commissioned by the Martin Luther King, Jr. Center  for Non-Violent Social Change.  Produced and written by Richard Kaplan it chronicles the life and work of Martin Luther King, Jr.  It recounts Dr. King's fight for social justice, human rights and the principle of equality for all.  
Narrated by James Earl Jones, Legacy includes rare footage of King's speeches, protests, and arrests using contemporary film/newsreel and video/television footage to brilliantly convey the boiling indignation of an oppressed people and their movement to secure equal rights.









"...a piece of history of immense power" - LA Times

"Perhaps the most important film documentary ever made. "- The Philadelphia Bulletin
"When [young people] see this film, they will not only understand it, but will also experience it to the depths of their souls."-The Washington Daily News


LEGACY OF A DREAM is both a history of the non-violent, civil rights movement and a portrait of the movement's inspiring leader, Martin Luther King, Jr.  It is a cinematic national treasure that will provide students with first hand knowledge of their own history and allow them to witness King's crusade.  It will give a greater appreciation of the challenges he endured and the vast legacy he left behind.







TEACH A NEW GENERATION ABOUT THE RIGHT TO PROTEST FOR RIGHT! 
Share the Legacy mission by contributing to IndieGoGo.
Learn more about Legacy of a Dream at http://alivemindcinema.com/legacy

story:
I'm Ai Ana.

I am a sophomore at a very small charter school in Oregon. I go to a school where education is valued higher than the facilities they're taught in, meaning many things are held together with duct tape and prayers. I'm taking a few AP classes and am very involved with my community.  
We are going on a trip to France and I have around $500 to raise to go in March. This is a lot of money, so I'm turning toward you to help. This is a once-in-a-lifetime experience, and I have nurtured a life-long love of French culture. This provided me with an opportunity to actually witness so much of this first hand. 
I've raised $2300 so far. But I need $500 more in order to get there. I've included awesome perks, such as cool French souvenirs ($20), chocolates ($100), and even a shoutout video and poem written especially for you, if you donate $200.
If I don't reach my goal and can't go, I'll put aside the money for college. I want to study mammal behavior and then apply this for mammal conservation and working in the field. 

The Impact

I feel that this will be a life-changing trip for me. I'd love to get the opportunity to travel around France and learn about the culture and language, and I'd like to apply this knowledge to my life. For instance, I'd love to travel around northern Africa, where they speak a lot of French. I'd also love to visit France for college, and perhaps even live there. I also love to write, and I've always been fascinated with French history... maybe a novel? These are all just little dreams I'd love to fulfill, and making a contribution is the way for me to do this. It's only the first step, but with one step, can't you change the world? I'm a dreamer and a doer, I want to go out and change the world, and I really believe this trip will help me accomplish just that.
France has always been a place I've loved, even as a small child, and I have emotional connections with the place. It has such a rich history and culture, and I've love the opportunity to see this for myself. It would be fulfilling a lifelong dream I've cultivated over many years, and it would mean so much to me to be able to see these almost legendary places and stories. It makes me feel like I've been there.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know this is a lot of money, and I know that this is a lot to ask. So even if you can't contribute money, you can do other things to support, like spreading the word around and raising awareness.

story: I recently was accepted into the JSA summer school at Stanford University. I will be studying many things including constitutional law. I hope to one day become a lawyer and this program would be a great stepping stone to further my educational career. However, I will need $4,750 to pay for this month long program, which would include money for my room and board, as well as $700 for the airfare to get out to California. If I do not reach my entire goal I hope to still be able to attend the program by utilizing other forms of fundraising. My mom teaches special education and because she is already working extra hours at an after school program to pay for travel volleyball I do not see her being able to afford this program as well.

story:
བཀྲ་ཤིས་བདེ་ལེགས། The Tibetan refugee community in India is building a new college, in part to educate future Tibetan teachers for the growing Tibetan Children’s Village (TCV).  Today there are 8 residential schools that house, feed, and educate 16,000 Tibetan orphans and refugee children from Tibet.  This new college, The Dalai Lama Institute for Higher Education, needs a modern library, and an alternative to intermittent electrical power and expensive BSNL Internet fees.  Here’s my campaign to do it! 

Campaign Goals

  1. To install an eGranary Digital Library and WiderNet server at the Dalai Lama Institute for Higher Education in Bangalore, India. 
  2. To build a campus-wide “Knowledgesphere” with wifi and wired network to provide access in the library, the dorms, the computer labs, and in the teacher workrooms.  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1Aeza6ehMzg

What’s an eGranary, you ask?  The eGranary Digital Library - also known as "The Internet in a Box" - provides millions of digital educational resources to institutions lacking adequate Internet access or funds for high speed institutional subscriptions.  The 4TB eGranary delivers over 30 million web sites, documents, films, books, journals, and educational software--fully indexed and searchable using our powerful, built-in search engine.  It can be instantly accessed by teachers and students over a local campus network (LAN) at no cost.  For a full content description, see: http://www.widernet.org/eGranary/

And where is this eGranary going?  The Dalai Lama Institute for Higher Education outside Bangalore, India was dedicated in Feb 2009 by His Holiness.  It is the site of the teacher training program for Tibetan Children’s Village (TCV) campuses in India. The Institute also has a School of Computer and Information Sciences, the future computer tech teachers for TCV schools. It's a new school with a limited library!

So what’s my money going to?  Your donation will buy the eGranary Digital Library and server ($3500), and the hubs, routers, wifi devices, wires/connectors, UPS backups, LED projectors, and tools to build this "Wi-Max Backbone" network for all teachers and students on campus.

Is this the real deal?  We are endorsed by Tenzing Sangpo, past TCV Education Director, and Dr Bob Hetzel, Director of the American Embassy School in New Delhi. We have a small grant from Hewlett (see pdf file in Gallery) for travel for the training, and to provide a stipend for two Tibetan faculty members. We do NOT have funds for hardware.

Who are you again?  I am David Quegg, Iowa City, IA.  I taught in the elementary division of the American Embassy School (AES) in New Delhi, 1998-2010.  I was also the school's liaison to Tibetan Children’s Village, and over the years developed a personal commitment to Tibetan refugee children and TCV. Previously we built an elementary science activities center in Dharamsala, a middle school science lab in Golpalpur, and installed two eGranary servers in those TCV senior section libraries,-- using donations from AES faculty and parents, and Iowa friends.  See: eGranary Showcased at Tibetan Children's Village Golden Jubilee Celebration   http://www.widernet.org/newsroom/newsletters/september2010

Today I am retired, but I continue as a volunteer in the WiderNet office here at the University of Iowa. Thu je che! (thank you) ཐུགས་རྗེ་ཆེ་།

story:
Short Summary

My name is Stella Sata and I am working with a UK Registered Charity called Friends of Monze raise funds to rebuild a community school in Monze, Zambia, Southern Africa. 

This campaign is important to me because I value education so much and I have been priviledged enough to have studied at good schools. When I went to Lushomo Community School, I felt a pang of heart ache when I saw the environment that my fellow Zambians were studying in. I was amazed by their zeal and enthusiasm despite the circumstances. I believe this is the same feeling that Mrs. Deana Owen(the founder of Friends of Monze) must have had when she lived in Monze. At Friends of Monze, we are DETERMINED to make this project a success and build Lushomo Community School a new school.

The total funds that are needed for the entire project is GBP 30, 000 but I have already raised GBP 2, 000 from donations from my facebook friends. 

Find a break down of what we will use the money for below.

When you give to this project, you won't only be giving to the 250 pupils who are currently studying at Lushomo Community School, but you will be giving to those who will come after them! Isn't that amazing?!


What We Need & What You Get

We need GBP 28, 000. Like I mentioned, we have already raised GBP 2, 000 which covers the Foundation Structure.

The GBP 28, 000 will be used for buying the building materials that are needed and for paying the builders. (This means that not only are you helping us rebuild a school, you are also providing people with employment!)


There are three stages that will be funded with the GBP 28, 000
1. Supper Structure - GBP 11, 000

2. Roof Construction and Cladding - GBP 4, 500

3. Finishes - GBP 4, 500

3. Labour - GBP 5, 000

4. 10.7 % Contingency Cost- GBP  3, 000

5. 9% Fees to indiegogo - 2520


What you get in return:


An email with updates on the building.

A Painting from one of Monze's children

Your name added on the Wall of Appreciation after completion

A Statue made in your honour.

The Awesome feeling of knowing that YOU HAVE BUILT A SCHOOL in AFRICA.

The Impact

  • First of all, you will give someone a source of income as they rebuild the school.

  • Second and most importantly, every day a child will go to a school that has white walls, a black board, proper toilets and desks, and though they will not know you, they will have you to thank for giving them the HOPE that they are not forgotten. That is your legacy! No one can take it away from you. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word! Tweet the link, Facebook it! Put it on Instagram.
  • You can also email me for a flier and banner template to put at your school, raise the money then send it back to us! Be our Ambassador!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
EYE ON BLACK 2014: GIVING BACK TO HOWARD UNIVERSITY, SCHOOL OF COMMUNICATIONS

GOAL TO RAISE $10,000 TOWARD SCHOLARSHIPS AND NEW EQUIPMENT

OUR HBCU’s ARE IN A CRISIS AND WE NEED YOU TO ACT NOW!


Our Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) are in crisis! Over the past several years, many HBCUs are have been faced with tough financial times closing dormitories, cutting programs, laying off professors and shedding scholarships! 

If this pattern continues, many HBCUs will be forced to close their doors after being in existence for over 150 years. WE CAN NOT AND WILL NOT LET THIS HAPPEN. 

With the lack of federal funding, alumni giving, low admission rates and aging facilities, many HBCUs students are far behind their counterparts at larger mainstream colleges.

The Eye on Black (EOB) program in 2014 has selected the Howard University, School of Communications as the benefactor of the year-long initiative .


2014 Campaign Overview:

The Eye on Black salute returns in 2014 with a specific focus on furthering the legacy of African Americans in the media and film industries. In 2014 we are making a commitment to black education and specifically select the Howard University School of Communication as our 2014 benefactor for the EOB Innovation Grant.

Hollywood Commitment to Black Education Prospective:

We ask you to consider extending your funding support specifically to Howard University through the EOB Innovation grant offered to entering senior students. This grant will be under your namesake and offered to up to two (2) students that will use this grant to assist in tuition costs, summer travel to internship and a fall mentorship.

What YOUR Innovation Grant will provide:

  • Scholarships to qualified Howard University Seniors
  • EOB hosting partner for Summer innovation internship two (2) students
  • Sponsor for Howard University Symposium and Luncheon

Your contribution will also go toward the funding of new equipment at our selected 2014 HBCU undergraduate broadcast program.

The Eye on Black Salute:

The Eye on Black salute takes place Academy Awards weekend and serves as an evening celebration set to recognize influential African-Americans in film, TV and in broadcast journalism. This event serves as a kick-off event for the year-long EOB innovation grant with our partner collegiate benefactor. 


The 2014 Eye on Black takes place Friday, February 28, 2014 at the California African American Museum. Tickets and tables are available for purchase at this event and all donors of the crowd-funding campaign receive discounts to the show and free VIP tickets for larger donations.


PAST GUESTS AND HONOREES:  Anika Noni Rose, Anthony Hamilton, Ava Duvernay, Barry Floyd, Bill Duke, Billy Dee Williams, Boris Kodjoe, Brandon T. Jackson, Brandy Norwood, DB Woodside, Debbie Allen, Elise Neal, Evan Ross, F. Gary Grey, Gary Dourdan, Goapele, Haile Gerima, Hill Harper, Jackee Harry, Jeanette Jenkins, Judge Mathis, Kenny Lattimore, Kevin Frazier, Khalil Kain, Kim  Whitley, Kimberly Elise, Leela James, LeToya Luckett , Luke Wilson, Macy Gray, Martin Lawrence, Mary Mary, Michael Jai White, Miki Howard, Naturi Naughton, Nia Long, Omar Gooding, Salli Richardson Whitfield, Sean Patrick Thomas, Sharon Leal, Sherri Shepard and Lamar Sally, Sheryl Lee Ralph, Stan Verrett, Suzanne De Passe, Tamar Braxton, Tatyana Ali, Tim Allen, Tim Story, Tommy Davidson, Yvette Nicole Brown, Martin Lawrence, Sidney Poitier and more...



How You Can Help?

We are in desperate need of your donations to assist in developing the EOB Innovation Grant to save our HBCUs and offer critical funding to deserving students. These students have made a commitment to receiving a higher education and they are our future global leaders in media, influencing world views on pop culture. 


Your donations of $50-$1500 will 100% go toward students in need of your donations! If you didnt go to an HBCU, look at this keystone donation as a chance to help a student that wouldn't be able to purchase books, pay for tuition or get to class on public transportation without your support. 


WE NEED YOU TO ACT NOW!

story:
My name is Sri Charan. I'm an actor and filmmaker from Los Angeles, CA.

Clean Slate Project is a script-to-screen project that aims at enhancing self- expression and imagination for underprivileged kids through the art of storytelling.

This project is being done in association with Myrtle Social Welfare Network, a UNICEF recognized NGO, which has been working to create opportunities, hope and self-respect among underprivileged children since 2000.  They’ve conducted hundreds of workshops, camps and Muppet shows for the most marginalized and vulnerable sections of society all across Tamil Nadu.

Sathya Children Education Sponsorship Programme is a single-parent children project initiative of Myrtle, which provides education support for children who are at the verge of discontinuing their education because of abject poverty.

We’ve chosen three very special kids from the Sathya Programme.

In the next few weeks, three up-and-coming filmmakers, including me, will be mentoring these kids one-on-one. With the help of storytelling workshops and games, we will assist the children in sharing a story of their own – real or fictitious – the sky is the limit! 

These stories will then be converted into a screenplay format and be made into films. The kids will have complete ownership over the script and will be given writer credits. The films will be made under the guidance of the renowned Tamil filmmaker Vasanth. Known for being realistic, his films have been described as a "middle path" between parallel and commercial cinema, revolving around social themes and relationships. His guidance will certainly be an added advantage.

About the Writers:

Ananthi:

Ananthi’s father Mr.Ganesan, 46, has been living with HIV/AIDS for the last eight years and is now infected with multiple diseases. Despite his ailing health, he still feeds his family of five by working as a tricycle loader – a day job in the scorching Chennai heat, transporting heavy loads from one end of the city to another. Ananthi’s mother is a housemaid and works in more than four homes a day to provide additional support for the family. Mr.Ganesan has three children.  Anand is the eldest and studies ITI (a technical under-graduation course) while also assisting his father by working as a tricycle loader.  Ananthi (our child-writer) is the second child and just got promoted to 9th grade. In addition to her school routine, she helps her mother with cooking and other household work.  Akash is the third child and is in 7th grade.  In addition to his family's dire situation, Akash faces the challenge of being a slow learner, and yet he still pushes himself to continue his studies.

Isharani:

Isharani’s mother, Elizabeth, is the only earning member of the family, supporting her ailing parents and two minor children. The first child, Ajithchandran, just completed 12th grade and is awaiting his results. He is also a volleyball district-level player and aims to go on to a higher level in the sport. Our child-writer, Isharani, is the second child and has just finished 10th grade. She is a trained Bharat Natyam (Traditional dance of Tamil Nadu State) dancer and hopes to continue to pursue her passion for dance.

Srinivasan

Our child-writer Srinivasan, 13, is a hearing-impaired child (deaf and mute). His father was just thirty-six years old when he died last year (in 2013) due to a massive heart-attack.  He collected old papers for recycling. After his death, all the family responsibilities were relegated to little Srinivasan and his mother.  His mother, who had been a house-wife until 2013 now finds herself working three jobs in different industries, including cleaning the roads for Chennai Corporation.  Srinivasan’s younger brother is Danabal, a 6-year-old is in 1st grade. The youngest child, Jenifer, is 5 years old.  She is also deaf & mute and will begin school this year. Additionally, this family has more dependents which include both Srinivasan’s grandmothers and his distant cousin, Yamini, 6, whose parents committed suicide due to financial problems.

About the Filmmakers:

Bala Murugan: 

An independent filmmaker from Madurai, Bala has worked as an Assistant Director and cameraman in several Tamil short and feature films.

His passion for movie making and unfading love towards children has brought him closer to this project. He hopes to bring the best out of the kids so that some day when they grow up, they can look back and draw inspiration from the wonders they created under his tutelage. He is currently working as an assistant with Arun Arumugam (see below) on a bi-lingual Tamil/English feature film.

Arun Arumugam:

With more than 12 years of experience as an Associate Director in the Tamil Film industry, Arun brings a myriad of talents to the table. He started his career as an AD for renowned directors like Pandiaraj & Vikraman and went on to co-direct a few feature films. He is now working on his first feature film as a director with Bala as the AD.

Contributions: 

Your contributions will go towards:

1)  Producing 3 short films written by our child writers.

2)  Establishing CSF as an organization.

3)  Sponsoring the children’s education.

4)  Submitting the films to festivals.

5)  Screening the films locally and internationally

6)  Merchandizing

By contributing time and/or money to this project, you will:

1)  Promote literacy through art.

2)  Improve the children’s self-expression.

3)  Encourage filmmakers to make socially responsible films.

4)  Help 3 passionate filmmakers do what they love to do – make films.

Thank you for your valuable time!

Sri
story_txt:
My name is Sri Charan. I'm an actor and filmmaker from Los Angeles, CA.

Clean
 Slate Project is a script-to-screen project that aims at enhancing 
self- expression and imagination for underprivileged kids through the 
art of storytelling.

This project is being done in association with Myrtle Social Welfare Network,
 a UNICEF recognized NGO, which has been working to create 
opportunities, hope and self-respect among underprivileged children 
since 2000.  They’ve conducted hundreds of workshops, camps and Muppet 
shows for the most marginalized and vulnerable sections of society all 
across Tamil Nadu.

Sathya Children Education Sponsorship Programme is
 a single-parent children project initiative of Myrtle, which provides 
education support for children who are at the verge of discontinuing 
their education because of abject poverty.

We’ve chosen three very special kids from the Sathya Programme.

In
 the next few weeks, three up-and-coming filmmakers, including me, will 
be mentoring these kids one-on-one. With the help of storytelling 
workshops and games, we will assist the children in sharing a story of 
their own – real or fictitious – the sky is the limit! 

These
 stories will then be converted into a screenplay format and be made 
into films. The kids will have complete ownership over the script and 
will be given writer credits. The films will be made under the guidance 
of the renowned Tamil filmmaker Vasanth.
 Known for being realistic, his films have been described as a "middle 
path" between parallel and commercial cinema, revolving around social 
themes and relationships. His guidance will certainly be an added 
advantage.


About the Writers:

Ananthi:

Ananthi’s
 father Mr.Ganesan, 46, has been living with HIV/AIDS for the last eight
 years and is now infected with multiple diseases. Despite his ailing 
health, he still feeds his family of five by working as a tricycle 
loader – a day job in the scorching Chennai heat, transporting heavy 
loads from one end of the city to another. Ananthi’s mother is a 
housemaid and works in more than four homes a day to provide additional 
support for the family. Mr.Ganesan has three children.  Anand is the 
eldest and studies ITI (a technical under-graduation course) while also 
assisting his father by working as a tricycle loader.  Ananthi (our 
child-writer) is the second child and just got promoted to 9th grade.
 In addition to her school routine, she helps her mother with cooking 
and other household work.  Akash is the third child and is in 7th grade.  In addition to his family's dire situation, Akash faces the challenge of being a slow learner, and yet he still pushes himself to continue his studies.

Isharani:

Isharani’s
 mother, Elizabeth, is the only earning member of the family, supporting
 her ailing parents and two minor children. The first child, 
Ajithchandran, just completed 12th grade
 and is awaiting his results. He is also a volleyball district-level 
player and aims to go on to a higher level in the sport. Our 
child-writer, Isharani, is the second child and has just finished 10th grade.
 She is a trained Bharat Natyam (Traditional dance of Tamil Nadu State) 
dancer and hopes to continue to pursue her passion for dance.

Srinivasan

Our
 child-writer Srinivasan, 13, is a hearing-impaired child (deaf and 
mute). His father was just thirty-six years old when he died last year 
(in 2013) due to a massive heart-attack.  He collected old papers for 
recycling. After his death, all the family responsibilities were 
relegated to little Srinivasan and his mother.  His mother, who had been
 a house-wife until 2013 now finds herself working three jobs in 
different industries, including cleaning the roads for Chennai 
Corporation.  Srinivasan’s younger brother is Danabal, a 6-year-old is 
in 1st grade. The youngest child, Jenifer, is 5 years old.  
She is also deaf & mute and will begin school this year. 
Additionally, this family has more dependents which include both 
Srinivasan’s grandmothers and his distant cousin, Yamini, 6, whose parents committed suicide due to financial problems.

About the Filmmakers:

Bala Murugan: 

An
 independent filmmaker from Madurai, Bala has worked as an Assistant 
Director and cameraman in several Tamil short and feature films.

His
 passion for movie making and unfading love towards children has brought
 him closer to this project. He hopes to bring the best out of the kids 
so that some day when they grow up, they can look back and draw 
inspiration from the wonders they created under his tutelage. He is 
currently working as an assistant with Arun Arumugam (see below) on a 
bi-lingual Tamil/English feature film.

Arun Arumugam:

With
 more than 12 years of experience as an Associate Director in the Tamil 
Film industry, Arun brings a myriad of talents to the table. He started 
his career as an AD for renowned directors like Pandiaraj & Vikraman and went on to co-direct a few feature films. He is now working on his first feature film as a director with Bala as the AD.

Contributions: 

Your contributions will go towards:

1)  Producing 3 short films written by our child writers.

2)  Establishing CSF as an organization.

3)  Sponsoring the children’s education.

4)  Submitting the films to festivals.

5)  Screening the films locally and internationally

6)  Merchandizing



By contributing time and/or money to this project, you will:

1)  Promote literacy through art.

2)  Improve the children’s self-expression.

3)  Encourage filmmakers to make socially responsible films.

4)  Help 3 passionate filmmakers do what they love to do – make films.



Thank you for your valuable time!



Sri

story:
What is Project Inspire?

Are you ready to be part of a movement? We know our youth need inspiration in their lives, cultural empowerment to remember their place of power in the world, and preparation for the opportunities that await them. 

That's what we do at Project Inspire.

The mission of Project Inspire is to empower youth and young adults through powerful personal, educational and professional opportunities to using the arts as a gateway to achievement..., and we've been doing so for 9 years as an initiative and the past 2 years as a 501 (c)(3) organization in schools and programs in Philadelphia, Florida, Washington, D.C., and Maryland through our scholarship and youth empowerment programs. 

Now, we're ready to go public and make our 100% volunteer-run movement even bigger.

You can find out more about us at http://www.inspirethemovement.org.

Help us to make our youth's dreams come true!

What We Need & What You Get

What we need:

We're hoping to raise $2,000 to go toward the following initiatives:

  • $200 book scholarships for students in Florida and Washington, D.C. as they enter into their first year of college
  • Event space and materials needed to implement our Youth, Education, Empowerment & the Arts programs in schools and communities
  • Funding to cover operational costs including insurance, meeting space, etc.

In return, you get the following perks:

  • $10 - Superstar Donation: You get a personal note from our Executive Director
  • $20 - Launch Party Ticket Donation: You get to attend our launch party in Washington, D.C. on 6/19 at Madam's Organ!
  • $50 - Inspirational Funder Donation: Thank you for being an inspiration! For this donation, you'll get a mention on our website as one of our 2014 Inspirational Funders + you get to attend our launch party in Washington, D.C. on 6/19 at Madam's Organ!
  • $100 - Empowering Funder Donation: Thank you for empowering our youth! For this donation, you'll get a mention on our website as one of our 2014 Empowering Funders + you get to attend our launch party in Washington, D.C. on 6/19 at Madam's Organ!
  • $200 - Foundation Builder Donation: Thank you for playing an integral role in laying a firm foundation for our youth! For this donation, you'll get a mention on our website as one of our 2014 Foundation Builders + you get to attend our launch party in Washington, D.C. on 6/19 at Madam's Organ!

With your help, we KNOW we can reach our goal!

The Impact

About our scholarship program:

  • Through this program, young women from under-resourced high schools participate in a multi-step program in which career and college preparation, as well as self and community empowerment-oriented assignments, are completed and submitted to help lay the foundation for success!
  • Thus far, 16 recipients have received almost $3,000

Through our youth empowerment program:

  • Each personalized workshop integrates the performing arts, empowerment, and components we feel will make specific participants successful: College and Career Preparation; Life Skills; Arts; and Self and Community Empowerment (CLAS). 
  • From 2003 until now, our program partners in Philadelphia, Florida, Washington, D.C., and Maryland have benefited from our empowerment programs!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Our youth deserve it!
  • You can share right on this page!

Go forth, and Inspire the Movement!

story:
Support "Let's Talk Native..."

"Let's Talk Native...with John Kane" is the only radio show of its kind anywhere. Native talk radio is almost non-existent compared to other media. I am John Kane. I have been an Native activist (Mohawk) for most of my adult life. Four years ago I bought a one hour timeslot to start the "Let's Talk Native..." show on a small AM station. Today I broadcast weekly for two hours on a 50,000 watt station in Buffalo, NY. The show streams live on the station's web site, my Native Pride blog and on TuneIn. LTN is paid programming and needs support to cover the airtime costs. The purchase of airtime allows me and LTN to cover tough Native issues without compromise. For two hours each week listeners have an unparalleled opportunity to hear a live, free form, Native radio talk show with open lines and a broadcast range that spans the entire the East Coast.

Contributions on this campaign will go directly to cover LTN's airtime.  

Airtime Costs

The bottom line is that this campaign needs to raise $9000 to cover just one quarterly bill for LTN's airtime.

I pay for my airtime quarterly, every 13 weeks. My cost per week is just under $700 for studio, production and airtime.

Your donations will ensure that this show continues and grows. LTN will show its appreciation for your contributions in various ways according to the donation levels.

  • First and foremost, all those that contribute will continue to get access to the only radio show of its kind and know that LTN is only possible because you stepped up. Supporting this program not only tells the world you care but also that you are in the fight for Native issues.
  • $25 will get your name read live and forever replayed in our archived shows as a basic "donor."
  • $100 will have your name added to a produced "contributor" spot that will run each week during the next quarter.
  • $1000 "sponsors" will be specifically mentioned in a studio produced spot acknowledging their support level and special gift package from Native artisans

All contributions, regardless of whether the funding goal is met, will go directly toward airtime funding. 

The Impact of Your Contribution

"Let's Talk Native..." is well into its fourth year. This show has shaped public opinion on a full range of Native issues over the years. The impact that LTN has had on policy makers, activists, educators and the mainstream media continues to grow. Your contributions turn this show's impact into your impact. You will be a solid and significant part of making the show possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Beyond contributing financially to the show, you can help by spreading the word about this campaign. You can help me by telling everyone you know about the importance of supporting the show and the value and benefits to all of us who are committed to these important issues.

  • Email links to this Indiegogo campaign to as many as possible and encourage those you share this with to do the same. The strength of this fundraising campaign is in the outreach.
  • Post the link on Facebook, Twitter, Google+, Blogger, Tumbler and all other social media platforms. And do it often. Hit the group pages too. This is a 60 day campaign so this Indiegogo link can be shared 10 or 12 times before it's over.
  • Talk up the show and urge people to search for and support this fundraiser.

story:
MISSION and FEATURES

Victoria Ryan O'Toole, children's author and creator of the Molly Moccasins book series is on a mission to give a FREE BOOK to every kindergarten child transitioning to the first grade in the public school system throughout the United States (as well as connect children, parents and educators AROUND THE WORLD to a FREE DIGITAL LIBRARY of nearly 70 more stories and games for connecting anytime, anywhere).

"We believe that igniting and encouraging curiosity in children is essential in the 21st Century. We know engaging children through story is a direct path to opening their minds to new ideas, new vocabulary and provides an opportunity for their imaginations to soar (which supports creative problem solving and innovation throughout their lives!). We understand that children connect with stories in various ways, from print to audio to visual and digital experiences. We hope to blend the school-to-home and home-to-school connection so learning does not begin nor end at either door."

Offering young learners the gift of options and opportunities at that crucial moment of transition in their lives is the driving force behind the CURIOUS KINDER BOOK PROJECT, with hope that those wonderful curious minds will never be bored—ever!

2014 Pilot Program -- CURRENTLY IN ACTION!

·  3,000+ Molly And Her Moccasins books will be distributed in May and June to a handful of kindergarten children transitioning to first grade throughout Southern California Public Schools (as well as to their teachers and school libraries).

·  Local creator and author will personally sign each book, speak to school groups and deliver books in May and June (as scheduling allows).

·  The official rollout will commence throughout the US in May of 2015.

DIGITAL LIBRARY FOR ALL -- SERIES IN SHORT

Molly Moccasins was inspired by a parent who was given a powerful gift as a child—a sentence inscribed in her first dictionary, “A curious mind is never bored.” From that day on, her curiosity was ignited and now she shares the joy (and rewards!) of being curious and asking questions with children around the world through the character, Molly Moccasins.

STORY THEMES

With the story themes provided by nearly 70 books, Molly Moccasins, provides a fun and safe learning environment where children can follow their curiosity and delight in a world of adventures on and off screen. Molly is constantly surprised and excited by the simple discoveries each day places in her path. With her toes tingling in her magical moccasins, she steps into amusing adventures that arise from everyday experiences which awaken her sense of wonder and imagination while building a vast and varied foundation of knowledge.

WEB EXPERIENCE

The KIDSAFE certified, intuitive, interactive and story-driven digital play space of Molly Moccasins offers children, parents and educators learning and exploration opportunities with a simple click of either LIBRARY or GAMES for access anytime and anywhere (with an internet connection!).

 DIGITAL LIBRARY BOOK FEATURES (nearly 70 titles)

·  Animation

·  Voiceover Narration

·  Text Highlighting

·  Multicultural References and Characters

·  Engagement for Various Types of Learners: Traditional, Reluctant, Auditory & Visual

 GAMES & ACTIVITY OPTIONS

·  Printable Coloring Books

·  Fun Facts

·  Picture Puzzles

·  Activity Pages

·  Connect the Numbers

·  Silly Sentences

·  Molly Matching

·  Splash Coloring

·  Word Scramble

·  ePainting

·  Word of the Day

·  Dress Up

COMING SOON…

Some exciting educational features are currently being planned for each of our nearly 70 books that will also be available as a FREE RESOURCE for educators, children and parents around the world.

·  STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art & Math) Read & Discover Guides

·  Common Core State Standards alignment

·  Foreign Language editions 


WHAT WE'LL DO WITH THE FUNDS

The first $7,500 will aid in our continued efforts to put more books in the hands of children (already our pilot program in LA is giving away 3,000 books to kindergarten children transitioning to first grade!).

We will also be able to create some branding elements like a logo and develop a website for registering schools in our official rollout of 2015. In addition, we will create a digital catalogue of titles and options as well as begin our campaign of connecting with appropriate educators and librarians.

Our stretch goal is to rapidly develop and release the enhanced educational features for each of our nearly 70 titles: STEAM Read & Discover Guides, the Common Core State Standards alignments and the Foreign Language editions.

Ultimately, and in addition to the funds received through indiegogo, the Curious Kinder Book Project will attempt to reach the 3.5 MILLION kindergarten children transitioning to the first grade each year in the United States and be funded by purchases of the limited edition print releases of additional Molly Moccasins Book Series titles (10 titles per year, for the next five years), donations, grants and endowments.

HOW YOU CAN HELP (and some perks!)

Each and every contribution or sharing of our efforts for the Curious Kinder Book Project is profoundly appreciated and will make a difference in the lives of our youngest learners!

Giving a child a book that is entirely theirs, one they can write in and make their own, is beautiful to witness. Beyond the colorful story, some fun facts and activities included in our limited edition book of, Molly and her Moccasins, there is a space for children to write their own names in the front and an entire COLORING BOOK in the back complete with space for children to WRITE THEIR OWN STORY! 

For your generosity and support, we’ve listed some perks that we hope you will enjoy with TWO OPTIONS for each. One is so that YOU, your family and community will benefit from the perks, and the other is for those wishing to contribute their perks directly to children in the CKBP Pilot Program--these are the "no ship" options listed. 

No matter where we are delivering the perks, we are incredibly excited about delivering them all!

IMPACT

The Curious Kinder Book Project is not just for kindergarten children (those are just the youngest learners in the US who will receive the FREE BOOKS). ALL CHILDREN, families and educators around the world will hopefully benefit from the Curious Kinder Book Project as supporting it will allow the Molly Moccasins digital library to be FREE (which further allows for the addition of those exciting educational enhancements too!).

THANK YOU 

Sincere and heartfelt thanks for your time, consideration and helping us not only ignite curiosity in children through story, but also sharing that one simple sentence that can make a difference in the lives of so many, "A curious mind is never bored!"

that we hope you will enjoy with TWO OPTIONS for each. One is so that YOU, your family and community will benefit from the perks, and the other is for those wishing to contribute their perks directly to children in the CKBP Pilot Program--these are the "no ship" options listed. No matter where we are delivering the perks, we are incredibly excited about delivering them all!IMPACTThe Curious Kinder Book Project is not just for kindergarten children (those are just the youngest learners in the US who will receive the FREE BOOKS). ALL CHILDREN, families and educators around the world will hopefully benefit from the Curious Kinder Book Project as supporting it will allow the Molly Moccasins digital library to be FREE (which further allows for the addition of those exciting educational enhancements too!).THANK YOU Sincere and heartfelt thanks for your time, consideration and helping us not only ignite curiosity in children through story, but also sharing that one simple sentence that can make a difference in the lives of so many, "A curious mind is never bored!"

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Michael. I am a 21 year old student from Cape Town, South Africa. In December 2011 I travelled for an AIESEC international internship to Hyderabad in India where I spent two months living and working in a children's home called Courtesy Foundation.

During this time I became like a big brother to the sixty children living in the home, I had the most amazing time of my life. The children have very little, their clothes are often tearing and they don't all have shoes, but they are full of joy and love and taught me an important lesson about life.

Throughout the two months, together with a few Brazilian and an Egyptian intern, we would eat every meal sitting with the kids, making sure not to elevate ourselves from them in any way, we bought them cookies and gifts, celebrated Christmas with them and flew kites for Sankranti (Indian harvest festival in January) and stood and saluted the Indian flag with them during the national anthem on Republic Day.

These kids love going to school, the home has its own small English language school on a plot next door, and you will never hear them say anything bad about their school day, though they get upset if they don't finish their homework on time.

I have been back to visit them once already in June 2012 when I surprised them and spent a further three weeks with them. I have fallen utterly and completely in love and not a day goes by that I don't miss the hugs from Kumar or Balu's smile or the great food.

When I went in June I brought them t-shirts which friends and family helped pay for. Now in January I've decided I want to make a bigger and longer lasting contribution to their lives. I want them to have books to read, reading was something I have always enjoyed and something I attribute a lot of my learning to rather than school, and its important for children to read so that they develop their language proficiency. 

What We Need & What You Get

Books in India, thankfully, are affordable. If you've ever wanted to pig out on a bunch of Stephen King's India is the place for you. I am trying to raise a mere $500 which may not seem like much, but in India this is equivalent to 25,000 rupees. With a children's book selling for an average of 300 rupees in a retail book store this would be enough to purchase 70 books and have 4000 rupees to spare for some shelving etc.

Now consider that I am planning to negotiate with book shops and possibly buy some second-hand books as well I am hoping this amount will be enough to get 100-150 books for the 60 kids at the home. This way every kid will always have a book to read and another to choose from without them having to fight and they will have enough books to last them a year or two considering a distribution for age group and language (their native tongue is Telugu, however they also learn Hindi and English in school).

The kids are aged 4 - 14 and mostly are in classes from Lower Kindergarten (LKG, age 4) to 4th class (age 10). So a variety from picture books to more elaborate children's books would be needed.

What do you get? Well, this isn't a commercial enterprise and no one is making a profit out of it or producing a good. So I can't offer to send you a product or anything of that sort.

However, you will get the great satisfaction of having made a tangible impact on 60 childrens' lives (not an anonymous donation that disappears in the depths of a multi-national NGO).

I will also share photos of the books, the book shelves and the kids reading and depending on your contribution will send you a printed photo with a thank you note on the pack. If you're erally generous I might even ask one of the kids to write you a letter ;).

The Impact

These 60 children come from diverse family backgrounds. Some are HIV orphans and suffering of HIV and AIDS themselves (a few in the final stages of the disease). Others are orphans or semi-orphans and others have been taken away from their families or the families can't take care of them any longer.

The home is a tiny organisation, started with just a few kids. They have an office with a few staff doing all the fundraising, but the magic happens at the home on the outskirts of Hyderabad. The manager has a wife, three kids and his mother to take care of, yet earns a salary of abour $120 and will still gladly spend his money on a birthday cake for one of the kids. 

He spends most nights away from his family to stay at the home and is the most gentle, loving and caring man I have ever met and I can truly say that he is a great friend of mine.

The kids, though they have little, are incredibly joyous and always happy. They most amazing thing is seeing the shine in their eyes when a visitor comes and no matter how small a donor's contribution they will all crowd around the entrance of the home as the donor leaves and shout bye and think you.

I have never met such well behaved and truly "good" children. However, though they learn English and Hindi in school their skill, especially in English, is lacking. They don't have anyone to speak English to and no books to practice with.

With the organisation struggling to meet their overheads every month to keep the children fed and warm and the teachers paid I want to help out with these books to give the kids a better chance at a good education and a better life when they grow up, because if anyone deserves it, they do.

Other Ways You Can Help

Other ways to help? Sure, you can collect books with friends and family and send them to the home itself! This would be after I've established the basic library and would be a great way to extend it further.

If you're in Hyderabad you should also come visit sometime during January when I am there and feel free to bring books, toys, food, clothes etc. or just bring some friends and some music and play with the kids for an afternoon!

story:
I have been admitted to the Portland Community College nursing class of 2015.  Yay! 

My quarter begins September 24th.  I am required to have all of my texts (~$1,200) before the start of classes.  I also need at least two navy blue scrub tops, two navy blue scrub pants, white shoes, and lightweight long-sleeved tops to wear as an underlayer.  I already have a stethoscope; it was Dan's.

My current employers are accustomed to me wearing rags, but I really don't want to start nursing school in Goodwill scrubs.

Because I have a prior degree, my financial aid eligibility is extremely limited, and this is the new economy, and this is Portland, Oregon.  I have very little work scheduled for the rest of the summer and none at all come September; My little ones are all beginning kindergarten or preschool and no longer require care. 

I can pay all of my bills and expenses until my financial aid comes through.  What I cannot manage is the added expense of my textbooks in particular. 

I will very much appreciate any assistance that you are able to provide.

Any and all funds recieved will go toward the cost of textbooks and school supplies.

If you would prefer to find used textbooks directly, please email me for specifics.

story:
I RAISED 4230 DOLLARS in my last crowdfunding campaign:

http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/kawawe-empowering-youth/x/3940840

I WENT on the Danish Radio News P3:

 http://www.dr.dk/Nyheder/Indland/2013/08/22/221829.htm

Now it is time for THE LAST MILE!

It is stated 5000 Dollars but my goal is 10000 Dollars 

(Indiegogo charges 9% if you do not achieve your goal)

My dream is to empower the youth by encouraging true bravery through the understanding of the self and subsequent realization of children’s own unique potential. My goal is to integrate self-development and dignity courses into our educational system, establishing critical life skills and techniques for children to acknowledge themselves and their peers as worthy individuals.

There seems to be an underlying but recurrent belief in our society of human inadequacy, whether it not being eligible for a university degree, taking a leadership position or simply being a good enough mother. This belief is cemented in children’s education very early on and leads to anxiety, stress and fear, as they get older. Thus, I think it is fundamental to make a positive impact in the world, starting with people in a young age to create a stronger change in the future and it is to accomplish this purpose that I gratefully receive donations.

To achieve this goal I will enroll a graduate education at Naropa University in Boulder, Colorado by the end of August 2013. I plan to dedicate the next three years in studying and practicing somatic psychology.

About me

My name is Nora, and if you already watched my video you know a few things about me, and why I am doing this.

Throughout my life I dealt with questions about being different from others, not only in my opinions but also in my way of looking and everything else that comes along with simply just “being”. 

Growing up in a Comorian* and Danish home and with an international education, I am accustomed to being surrounded by different cultures and languages both at my workplace, in my spare time, and while studying.

I have a strong interest in people and their personal development and therefore I have chosen to take my master's in psychology at this particular university that has a strong focus on the student’s personal growth to become a practicing psychologist.

You can find my CV here.

*Country in the Indian Ocean, situated at the north-west of Madagascar.

Kawawe

Kawawe is a Comorian word, based on the language bantu, meaning “to be yourself”. My father always used to teach me the value of this “word” while growing up; it was not until my 20s that I started understanding the significance of living and cultivating the authenticity of kawawe.

I am discovering kawawe every day and it’s my wish to transmit kawawe to further people.

Your Donation - My Impact

Through my four years in the largest volunteer student organization AIESEC, I had the gratifying opportunity to meet a lot of different people at different places around the world. I have worked with youth of all kinds of nationalities with the common vision to create a positive impact in society through the realization of humankind's potential. 

My work helped contribute in a large number of countries, namely in Malaysia, Denmark, Argentina, Chile and Uruguay. During my internship in Kuala Lumpur, I thought awareness about HIV/AIDS to over 200-university students. As president of AIESEC in my local committee I facilitated over 60 international internships abroad. In my latest endeavor as yearlong position in Buenos Aires as Director at AIESEC in Argentina, Chile and Uruguay, I opened 5 new AIESEC expansions in the region that contributed to over 50 leadership experiences. All contributions – donations – to a more positive impact in the world.

In my current job I work with a global business network of over 80 Goodwill Ambassadors, all with a common goal to promote Denmark globally and share the story of Denmark.

Likewise, it is now time for me to help out the youth to share their Kawawe story out in the world.

I have applied for various funds and been so fortunate to receive some funding. 

Now I really need some help in this final push in realizing my dream. Donations of any amount would be of a great value, and I would be extremely grateful for any help you could give.
