story:
Prelude

In order to play “the game” and win, the new generation of entrepreneurs needs “coaching“. What if you can have access to advice on building profitable startups from many other entrepreneurs, investors and specialists?

Still, reading theory on how to play doesn’t make you necessarily a good player. You need practice. What if you can see how others do it practically, at different development stages and with different backgrounds?

And also, is not really easy to understand something new, unless you make analogies. What if this new adventure is described to you as a parallel to something you already know very well and you like to do?

If this sounds appealing to you, I invite you to read my upcoming book: Customer Seduction. It will help you build a profitable tech startup by showcasing how other startups seduce(d) their customers.

It will offer you 100+ perspectives of well known entrepreneurs, investors and specialists from various industries and locations. It will be very practical, with plenty of examples, case studies, tools to use, paths to follow.

And it will be easy to follow, being presented as an analogy with the art of seduction (examples: how to build long term relationships with your customer aka retention, how to make customers fall in love at first sight aka design, user experience etc.)

Progress

Until launching this crowdfunding campaign on 9th October, I put up a team, a title and a theme and I realized the first 11 interviews on 3 continents and scheduled many more to follow. Already the knowledge gathered is impressive. I will share quotes and previews, but I want to sit and analyze the information, structure it, give it an interesting shape (packing it in a nice art of seduction) and publish it in December this year.

Until then, it would be great to see your support! Be our ANGELS in this campaign!

Yours truly,

Adelina

 

FAQ

What is it about?

The book addresses founders of early stage tech startups  that want to know:

  • how to gather and interpret customer feedback in product development
  • what it takes to get to product-market fit
  • how to do user acquisition
  • how not to scale prematurely
  • how to use metrics to understand growth potential and to convince investors to fund
  • how to form a team with the needed skills at different stages of development

 

Being based on 100+ interviews with entrepreneurs, investors and specialists, the book will provide practical know-how, case studies, recent tools and paths to follow.

Who is behind the book?

Author: Adelina Peltea 

Project Development: Catalina Dogaru

Community Development: Monica Pascanu 

Product Development: Mihai Zamfir

When and where will it be launched?

Launch is scheduled for 14th December 2012. It will be at first a digital book available at international level.  

Where can I check more details and previews?

An updated list of the work in progress of all the interviews with founders, investors and specialists can be found here. The blog offers details on the making-of (examples: interview stories, previews). A sample interview is available here.

I am an interested future reader. How can I get involved?

We are building a community around the book  that can submit suggestions and give feedback. We will take into consideration different needs you might have and can be covered by the book. So just let us know what you need and want to know. To interact, please join our social networks (facebook and twitter).

How and why would I support you through the making-of?

We launched this crowdfunding campaign and we would be happy to receive support. All of you who believe in our work before the launch and back us up will get mentioned in the book as supporters and will receive different perks. It is nice to see early interest while we work on it.

What is the story behind it?

There are lots of tech startups  that develop a product before checking the market fit, just based on assumptions. You can hear them while pitching that they use words like “I think”, “customers will have to” etc. There are lots of founders that are great technical or business people, but lack marketing knowledge and do not know how to reach potential customers best. There are  all sorts of books but with few practical examples and most of the showcases are only from US and not other areas.

Adelina Peltea, author of the book, realized all these gaps, especially while working on her startup (ytalent). She noticed that the best way to learn is by talking to other founders about deep things that are not disclosed in media stories. Then why not share the learning with other entrepreneurs? Consultancy would be great, but most early stage entrepreneurs would not afford it. Then the idea of publishing a book came along, which would make founders have affordable access to all the knowledge gathered from 100+ interviews. Besides, the revenues from book sales can be used as seed investment in Adelina’s startup, ytalent. That is a way to test if the learning from the book is actually actionable and can lead to success.

story:
Our Story

Jungle to Jungle makes science exuberant, wild, accessible, and most of all fun! It's "webducation" for kids and adults the world over.  Wading in the black waters of the Amazon, petting tapirs and crocodiles, and tromping through the most dangerous and exciting jungles in the world! Sound like a place for middle school students? Not really... which is why we take students on virtual field trips to exotic ecosystems around the world. Jungle to Jungle educates young people about the wild places all around them and teaches them to become adept in the latest technology. We want our students to be nature loving techies prepared for and loving this modern earth.


Science, tech, and international social skills all taught through the students' very own social networking site.


The program is designed to augment the standard middle school life science classroom curriculum and fulfills and exceeds national and state science education standards.

The Impact

We change the lives of students around the world by connecting them with each other and getting them excited about far off places. In this way, we encourage and educate them to be conscious world citizens.
 In addition to our science video web series, we provide photos, essays, and social networking for free on our website, so that students of all ages can access all of this exciting science knowledge and connect around the globe.

In our first two years, we have directly worked with 600 students in the United States, Peru, Colombia, and Borneo. In 2012, we plan to extend our reach further, into Polynesia, with future plans to work with students in Ecuador  Vietnam, Australia, Africa and Papua New Guinea.

Students today have so many exciting things going on around them, and we believe that school should be one of them. The education system hasn't changed in 100 years, but everything else has. It's time to start thinking outside the box about standardized education. It's 2011, the classroom shouldn't still be square.

What We Need & What You Get

We need money. Cash. Bones. In the past two years we have paid for this project mostly out of our own pockets. We have also thrown fundraisers and had some very generous private donations. For the Fall 2011 Project : Ring of Fire we are raising the funds through Indiegogo. (Thanks, Team!) We need $12,000 to purchase a new camera and do the expedition planning, curriculum development, web design, develop the student's social networking site, pay for hosting fees and project management. Any funds raised beyond our goal will be applied to Project 201: Papua New Guinea

What You Get:
A brighter, more enlivened and educated generation of people. Through our lenses, education is the solution to basically all the massive conundrums we as a global community are facing.

Other Ways You Can Help

Are you a fun or funny scientist or naturalist? 

We would love for you to be one of our experts that our students can grill about all things jungle.


We are looking for donations for our silent auction happening on August 20th. If you have anything to donate please contact us.


Are you a school in the United States or elsewhere that would like to be involved in our program?

Email Jill or Amanda.


Do you have a boat that travels around the world?

We're adventurers, so we just had to ask


Most importantly, please share this campaign with others. Remember, this is a numbers game. The more people that play the cheaper it is for everyone! Share this through Twitter, Facebook, Email, or word of mouth.


Thank you so much for your care, consideration, and support.

(We like you.)

For the Fall 2011 Project : Ring of Fire we are raising the funds through Indiegogo. (Thanks, Team!) We need $12,000 to purchase a new camera and do the expedition planning, curriculum development, web design, develop the student's social networking site, pay for hosting fees and project management. Any funds raised beyond our goal will be applied to Project 201: Papua New Guinea

What You Get:A brighter, more enlivened and educated generation of people. Through our lenses, education is the solution to basically all the massive conundrums we as a global community are facing.


Other Ways You Can Help
Are you a fun or funny scientist or naturalist? 
We would love for you to be one of our experts that our students can grill about all things jungle.

We are looking for donations for our silent auction happening on August 20th. If you have anything to donate please contact us.

Are you a school in the United States or elsewhere that would like to be involved in our program?
Email Jill or Amanda.


Do you have a boat that travels around the world?
We're adventurers, so we just had to ask

Most importantly, please share this campaign with others. Remember, this is a numbers game. The more people that play the cheaper it is for everyone! Share this through Twitter, Facebook, Email, or word of mouth.


Thank you so much for your care, consideration, and support. 
(We like you.)

story:
About a month ago, I released my free Naked Marketing manifesto.

The premise was simple: marketing has gotten too complicated.

All marketing is really about is aligning what you’ve got with what people want and then telling them about it, and used the metaphor of an intimate relationship to explain these steps in simple terms.

The response was overwhelming.

The manifesto has been shared and downloaded THOUSANDS of times, and critically acclaimed by industry thought leaders like Copyblogger Media’s Brian Clark, and Gini Dietrich, recent co-author of the bestselling Marketing in the Round.

Dozens of spin-off resources were created (and have racked up a collected tens of thousands of views themselves!), and there has been an enormous amount of discussion and excitement in the community.

Clearly, I hit a nerve.

Along with all that discussion, there has been an implicit (and sometimes explicit!) interest in learning more – like this response from Mary Jaksch (from Write to Done and A-List Blogging Bootcamps):

Oh, my - that manifesto is f%&*)$# hot, Danny!

The manifesto immediately revealed some fundamental mistakes I'm doing in my marketing ... ouch!

You're an awesome marketer ... WOW!

It quickly became clear to me that the manifesto might have shown them what they were doing WRONG, but it didn’t give them everything that they needed in order to get it RIGHT.

So I finally asked the simple question...

Does anyone want me to write a book about Naked Marketing?

First, I asked a few of my colleagues.

Then I reached out to some of my students, and then I asked all of my followers to fill out a survey telling me whether they would be interested in a book that shows, step-by-step, how to do everything that I describe in the Naked Marketing manifesto.

And the answer? It was a resounding YES, YES, YES from all over the world.

It doesn’t get much clearer than that!

Well, if everybody wants me to do this, how could I say no? ;-)

BUT (the infamous “but” again)...

I’ve been teaching marketing for a long time, with great results, but this is going to be my first time writing an entire book about the subject.

I’m excited and eager to do it, but I want to make absolutely sure that people actually want to read this book if I write it, and that it will be out-of-this-world AMAZING if I do.

And I’m pretty sure that the way books usually get written, that isn’t going to happen.

Here’s how books usually get written:

  1. The author has an idea for a great book, ideally because of a huge groundswell of interest from their community. (Check)
  2. The author goes away to a cabin or something for six months, to write in isolation. (Errr, not wild about that part)
  3. The author publishes the book, which reflects what the author *thought* the community wanted back when he started writing six months earlier. (That doesn’t sound promising at all!)

Maybe it’s just me, but this really DOESN’T sound like a recipe for success!

Which is why I’ve decided to do things a little bit differently:

I want YOU to help me write this book!

Instead of going away for six months and writing in seclusion, I want to write this book in collaboration with the people who need it the most.

I want to share my ideas with you as I write them, develop them in collaboration with you, and get your feedback and input before I waste time writing stuff that you aren’t interested in reading.

Then I’ll write up my ideas, and share them with you – every section and chapter – the moment that I’m done writing them. That way...

  • You’ll be able to apply these ideas right away, and report back about what you’ve done and how it worked.
  • You’ll be able to tell me what you like and what you don’t, so that I can make the book better than it ever could be if I was writing it alone.

This is a different way of writing a book, and I think it’s the best way – maybe the ONLY way – of writing a book about this subject that will be truly amazing.

Now, I’m sure you’ve already realized that getting involved means investing a small amount of your hard-earned money to this project.

There are two very good reason why this is true:

Reason #1: Books Cost Money

Yes, it’s true – there are costs involved in writing and publishing a book.

There’s proofreading and typesetting, there’s cover design, there’s ordering review copies to make sure it’s setup properly, and a whole bunch of other odds and ends.

And believe me, those odds and ends add up!

My last book, Engagement from Scratch!, was paid for by WebFaction and Photos.com; both organizations very generously sponsored the project, to the tune of about $6,000.

I’m not trying to raise nearly as much for this one; all I’m aiming for is $2,500 to cover basic project expenses.

But since this book is really for YOU, I think it’s only fair that you help to pick up the tab – to the tune of at least $25.

Especially because...

Reason #2: I Won’t Do This Alone!

I don’t want to spend the next six months of my life writing this book if you don’t absolutely want me to.

Let’s face it – filling out surveys is easy, but it’s when you have to spend a bit of your own money that you really demonstrate that you’re committed to something.

And I really do need you to be committed. I need your help to make this book amazing, and if you aren’t willing to even put a tiny bit of money into the project, I have to question how invested you’ll be in the entire process of doing this.

Besides, you’ll be in on this entire project from the very beginning, and that’s really valuable – much more than the tiny amount of money that it’ll cost to get involved.

Plus, if you decide to participate, you’ll get all kinds of perks...

Special Perks for my Writing Team!

I want to give you every reason to get behind this project, so I’ve put together a huge list of exciting perks that you can get when you join my Writing Team, like:

  • Privileged access to the book materials before anybody else
  • A direct line to me, and the ability to influence the development of the entire project
  • A behind-the-scenes look at how it all comes together
  • An autographed paperback copy mailed to your door as soon as it’s ready
  • Free access to the live Naked Marketing Bootcamp training series I’m developing
  • 1-on-1 marketing and business strategy advice and coaching from me (I usually charge $250 for 45-minutes)
  • Acknowledgement, mention, and exposure in the book when it’s released

The full list of perks is listed on the side of the page, and just to be clear, the perks are CUMULATIVE – so if your investment gets you the signed hardcover, for example, it’ll also get you participation in the project.

How to Join my Writing Team

It’s simple, really.

Just click on the CONTRIBUTE NOW button below, and fill out the form.

It’ll only take a couple of minutes.

Just choose your perk, fill out your information, and hit CONTRIBUTE – and you’ll be onboard.

I’m very, very excited to work with you on this!

See you on the inside,

Danny Iny
Firepole Marketing

story:
Our Story

Since 1946, Pine Canyon Camp has changed lives, serving youth, families and special needs groups.  From May 8 through June 25, 2011, the Horseshoe 2 Fire ravaged 80% of the incomparable Chiricahua Mountains (222,954 acres), destroying some of the most unique vegetation and ecosystems in the world. 

In the middle of this fire area lies the once active Pine Canyon Camp and Retreat Center.  The 15 acre Camp area (leased National Forest land) was mostly untouched by fire; the buildings were saved from fire damage by the firefighters (thank you!!!).  However, the runoff from the subsequent record monsoon rains of July through September 2011 (8.64 inches of precipitation) ran unchecked. The fire left the watershed above Pine Canyon Camp unprotected.  The Camp property has become unusable from the flooding and damage to the Camp’s grounds, facilities and equipment, as well as the road destruction, stream channel movement, and water system intake damage.

We need your help.

 

What We Need

Priorities include: re-establishing access by repairing the roads, rechanneling the stream channel, and establishing erosion control measures for now and the long-term to protect this fragile environment as well as the assets and usability of Pine Canyon Camp.

We are requesting funding to pay for the rental of heavy equipment needed to do the work of moving the dirt and rock that filled the creek channel, destroyed the access road and flooded the buildings.  It is also imperative to put long-term erosion control measures into place in order to protect the natural resources and promote forest recovery.  We have volunteers, both skilled and unskilled labor, ready to do the work necessary (we could always use more!).  We have located a dozer to rent for a reasonable rate and are estimating three months of work for this initial phase to reopen Camp.  Including labor, equipment rental fees,  maintenance, fuel, and materials, we are estimating a cost of $25,000 to complete the clean-up, repairs and erosion control. 

BUDGET

 

Description

Amount

     Extended

Equipment rental

$600/week x 13 weeks

$7,800

Equipment fuel and oil

$100/week x 13 wks

$1,300

Materials (gravel, cement, culvert, etc)

 

$3,900

Labor

$3000/mo x 4 mo

$12,000

Total

 

$25,000

 

All moneys received will go straight to our account to immediately begin the work.  We appreciate all the help!

 

Why is Pine Canyon Camp important?

Youth Camp

     One day I spied a pretty little girl about 8 or 9 years old, named Diane*, sitting at a picnic table.  I sat down across from her and casually asked her how her day was going.  She told me how fun it was in Arts & Crafts that morning.  I asked her if she made any new friends this week. She told me about a couple of the girls in her cabin and her counselor.  Somewhere in our discussion she told me that she had been recently adopted.  She told me about how she and her brother used to be homeless, living on the streets with their mother.  Her mother’s “medication” was just too expensive to afford a house to live in.  Sometimes, she said, they would sneak into the back door of her grandma’s house and grandma would feed them. They were really hungry! 

     At Camp she didn’t have to worry about being hungry (mmm . . . it was good!), she didn’t have to worry about where she was going to sleep, AND she could make friends and have fun! She was like everyone else when she was at Camp; she didn’t have to worry about anything when she was at Camp except just being a kid!

 

Camp Hope

     I met Ed*, an autistic 50+ year old man during our camp for developmentally disabled adults, Camp Hope.  The first year I met him, he spent the entire week on the porch at the one smoking spot available, chain-smoking.  He didn’t look at anyone and he didn’t speak to anyone.  He only came off the porch to eat and to go to bed.  Ed’s group home and Camp counselors told me that he looked forward to his week at Camp all year long.  By his third year, he was off that porch, occasionally participating.  By his fifth year, he was holding full conversations, maintaining eye contact, and participating joyfully in most of the Camp activities.

     In a few short years Ed went from an uncommunicative, closed off individual to a cheerful, talkative, happy man and a joy to be around.  He was helpful to his fellow campers and when he arrived home, he was an active member of his group home and community.

 

Strength for the Journey 

     On the last evening at the closing Campfire for our Strength For the Journey retreat (for HIV+/AIDS adults and their caregivers), Jane* stood up to speak.  What she said astounded us all.  She was 38 years old, had grown up on the streets and, like her mother, prostituted herself in order to buy her next high.  She ended up in jail for prostitution; while there she learned she was HIV+.

     That evening she told us “I thank God for giving me this disease.”  We all gasped.  “Because of this disease, I got to come to this retreat – I’ve never been to a place like this.  What I learned here is that I get to actually live whatever life I have left, instead of always looking for my next high, then being too drugged up to actually live.”

     Jane has since married her long-time boyfriend and has worked to regain her health, physically and emotionally.  It hasn’t been easy, but she continues to work towards her goal, with the help her friends she made at Camp.

 

* Names have been changed.

 

Studies done by the American Camp Association (ACA) show that one week spent at summer camp has the following benefits:

·        Children become more self-confident and experience increased self-esteem;

·        Children develop more social skills that help them make new friends;

·        Children grow more independent and show more leadership qualities;

·        Children become more adventurous and willing to try new things;

·        Children become more aware of the natural environment;

·        Children become better citizens.

Camp is good for families as well.  Studies done by the California Parks and Recreation Society (CPRS) show that:

·        Camping reduces stress in an increasingly demanding and stressful world.

·        Camping enhances overall health and well-being – critical to personal quality of life.

·        Camping significantly reduces health care costs – fitness and well-being reduces both the incidence and the severity of illness and/or disability.

·        Camping helps people live longer adding up to 2 years to life expectancy.

·        Camping builds strong families – the foundation of a healthy community.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please go to our website at www.pinecamp.org to learn how you can become a member of the Friends of Pine Canyon Camp and earn discounts and other great benefits.  

If you can't help financially, the next best way to help is to share this page far and wide. We need your help now before damage continues to escalate.

story: This campaign is to raise funds to purchase a park bench in Red Bank for Linda Rowe's Memorial.  We've already put the deposit down and have 30 days to raise the funds.  Please donate so all of Linda's Friends and Family will be able to sit down at her bench in the park and visit her in spirit.

story:
About myself---my name is Rose Angélica Arellano-Ramos.

I’m a 2nd generation latina, queer, 23 years young, student, community builder, activist, poet, writer, and an artist of various mediums. I’m being guided down a path. I have a deep trust that the Universe is leading me into becoming a certified yoga teacher so that I may continue to help others. 

Growing up my parents didn't have the money to pay for yoga classes. I learn a lot of self-hate towards my body, didn't learn how to take care of it properly and was extremely self-destructive. Yoga is fairly new to me but has already transformed my life in many ways. I am learning how to love myself and my body through yoga.

Since I was a teenager, I’ve been online vlogging to thousands of people around the world, helping by giving advice and teaching people how love themselves while going through my own journey of self-love.

I am based in Oakland, California, United States.

What do I plan on doing with my certification?

I have a lot of plans for my yoga teacher certification.

I plan on benefitting those around me first; family, friends and my Bay Area communities. These minority communities have little access to yoga studios or affordable yoga classes. People around me are less active, more stressed, less healthy, and emotionally unstable. Yoga has taught me to be centered in my daily life. 

I also plan on sharing various yoga routines with my community online via videos. I’ve got BIG dreams, you know. I travel every few years back home to Mexico. I plan on bringing my yoga knowledge to my family, friends and communities there as well. Where there is a need to bring peace of mind, I will be there and I will offer my practice to those who need it. 

I intend to offer yoga to low-income people, people of color, young women and girls, queer people of all genders, mothers with children, couples and anyone who reaches out to me. 

I want to connect to thousands more people with this practice.

Why yoga?

I want to become a conscious person. Yoga is my salvation and one of my missions in life. My body is a temple. Yoga is a deep and profound practice that has allowed me to see the value of my light. Yoga makes me feel grounded like I'm a part of something bigger than myself-connected through breath and feeling present in my body. When I do yoga, I feel aligned with my purpose in life. 

I am going to be taking a yoga teacher training program through Barefoot Yoga in Oakland, CA, USA. The cost is $2,450 for tuition, $1,200 for housing and lastly the additional fee that comes with using this website $255 totaling $3,905.        

If I do not make the whole amount I will not be in a financial position to take this training. 

Any extra money, over and above the goal will go towards other projects I am working on including building my own website, paintings, books I’m writing and intend to publish, as well as prints of my modeling and artwork.
 

What you get for helping!

For your generous donations, you will recieve a wide array of perks which could include the following; prints, photosets, a personalized video (advice, yoga, etc), or my prose/poetry writing upon request. I am infinitely gracious to have been lead to this website and I hope that I can meet my goal in time!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please donate what you can! $1, $3, $5, every little bit counts and means the world to me. Tell your family, friends, lovers, co-workers, anyone who might be interested in helping another person achieve one of their dreams. 

Gracias for supporting me in prayer and thought. I feel the love from my WORLD communities! Send me love on all social networks! It's much appreciated! 

If you don’t have access to a credit card and would still like to donate, please email me at ailobiu3(at)yahoo(dot)com SUBJECT LINE-Yoga Teacher Training Donation.
story_txt:
About myself---my name is Rose Angélica Arellano-Ramos.
I’m a 2nd generation latina, queer, 23 years young, student, community builder, activist, poet, writer, and an artist of various mediums. I’m being guided down a path. I have a deep trust that the Universe is leading me into becoming a certified yoga teacher so that I may continue to help others. 
Growing up my parents didn't have the money to pay for yoga classes. I learn a lot of self-hate towards my body, didn't learn how to take care of it properly and was extremely self-destructive. Yoga is fairly new to me but has already transformed my life in many ways. I am learning how to love myself and my body through yoga.
Since I was a teenager, I’ve been online vlogging to thousands of people around the world, helping by giving advice and teaching people how love themselves while going through my own journey of self-love.
 I am based in Oakland, California, United States.



What do I plan on doing with my certification?


I have a lot of plans for my yoga teacher certification. 
I plan on benefitting those around me first; family, friends and my Bay Area communities. These minority communities have little access to yoga studios or affordable yoga classes. People around me are less active, more stressed, less healthy, and emotionally unstable. Yoga has taught me to be centered in my daily life. 
I also plan on sharing various yoga routines with my community online via videos. I’ve got BIG dreams, you know. I travel every few years back home to Mexico. I plan on bringing my yoga knowledge to my family, friends and communities there as well. Where there is a need to bring peace of mind, I will be there and I will offer my practice to those who need it. 
I intend to offer yoga to low-income people, people of color, young women and girls, queer people of all genders, mothers with children, couples and anyone who reaches out to me. 
I want to connect to thousands more people with this practice.

Why yoga?
I want to become a conscious person. Yoga is my salvation and one of my missions in life. My body is a temple. Yoga is a deep and profound practice that has allowed me to see the value of my light. Yoga makes me feel grounded like I'm a part of something bigger than myself-connected through breath and feeling present in my body. When I do yoga, I feel aligned with my purpose in life. 

I am going to be taking a yoga teacher training program through Barefoot Yoga in Oakland, CA, USA. The cost is $2,450 for tuition, $1,200 for housing and lastly the additional fee that comes with using this website $255 totaling $3,905.        
If I do not make the whole amount I will not be in a financial position to take this training. 
Any extra money, over and above the goal will go towards other projects I am working on including building my own website, paintings, books I’m writing and intend to publish, as well as prints of my modeling and artwork.
 

What you get for helping!


For your generous donations, you will recieve a wide array of perks which could include the following; prints, photosets, a personalized video (advice, yoga, etc), or my prose/poetry writing upon request. I am infinitely gracious to have been lead to this website and I hope that I can meet my goal in time!
Other Ways You Can Help


Please donate what you can! $1, $3, $5, every little bit counts and means the world to me. Tell your family, friends, lovers, co-workers, anyone who might be interested in helping another person achieve one of their dreams. 
Gracias for supporting me in prayer and thought. I feel the love from my WORLD communities! Send me love on all social networks! It's much appreciated! 
If you don’t have access to a credit card and would still like to donate, please email me at ailobiu3(at)yahoo(dot)com SUBJECT LINE-Yoga Teacher Training Donation.

story:
Help Frans study Shugendo in Japan

Frans Stiene is a committed Reiki teacher who, in July 2012, has the unique opportunity to begin Shugendo training in Japan. YOU can help him to raise the funds to go.

Frans has been studying and teaching the system of Reiki from a Japanese perspective since 1999 all around the globe. Those of you who know Frans know that he is 100% committed to his roles as a Reiki teacher and as a student of the practice. His generosity in sharing his path with others is a stand-out amongst Reiki teachers.

It is unfortunate that there is little verifiable information about the system of Reiki and its founder available in Japan. Even though this is the case, Frans has made it his mission to try to gain as much insight into what the intentions behind the system were as well as what influenced the founder in its creation.

Shugendo is a Japanese practice that the founder of the system is believed to have practiced and we can see its influence on many of the traditional practices taught in the system of Reiki. Wouldn't it be incredible if there was a better understanding in the Reiki community about these practices?

Recently, an opportunity has come up for Frans to begin training with a Shugendo teacher in Japan. It is rare for a westerner to have this chance and the International House of Reiki wishes to support Frans in this endeavour.

We hope that you, too, would like to support Frans in furthering his knowledge and energetic skills. As a teacher he is in the perfect position to be able to give back to the community from this experience. You get the benefit of his hard work and committment. And we hope this is just the beginning for Frans' further study of Japanese practices.

How much does he need?

We worked out he needed approximately $3550 (Australian) to cover travel, living and teaching expenses.  That is broken down into:

  • Flight to Japan from Sydney $1000
  • Accommodation $1000
  • Food $500
  • Donation for Training $750
  • Extras (like Indiegogo %) $300
(7% of what you contribute goes to Indiegogo and if we dont reach our goal then they receive 12%)

What do YOU get out of this?

If you support Frans in his training, then he would like to support you directly back. You'll see on the right hand side some of the perks we have created just for you. No matter which perk you help out with, you will still get something personal in return.

All money raised will go towards getting Frans to Japan whether we receive the entire goal required or not. Naturally, we hope to acheive the goal AND if we receive more than the goal set out above we will be put it forward to further training for Frans in Japanese practices.

What Difference Will This Training Make?

We don't have much time to get this money together - so we need to reach our goal as quickly as possible.

The impact that this training in Japan will have on Frans' teachings will be significant, lifting even further his ability to connect energetically with students and to transfer teachings that will change people's lives for the better.

Frans' constant research over the years has shown that he is a teacher who doesn't give up and understands that to be the best teacher he can, he has to walk his talk. Frans doesn't just teach out of books, he teaches out of experience, and we hope to further this level of experience by sending him to Japan.

And one more thing... the more knowledge that the global Reiki community has about the system of Reiki, the better it is for practitioners everywhere - whether they study directly with Frans or not. Trained and experienced teachers like Frans give greater credibility to the system as a whole, making the system of Reiki the perfect complementary health & spiritual practice of choice.

Other Ways You Can Help

We get it that some of you may not be able to contribute - that's ok!

Perhaps you can help us in other ways? You could put out the call on twitter and facebook and even embed a little widget on your website explaining what we're trying to do.

You'll find all these share tools under the video at the top of this page.

We thank you for anything and everything that you can do to help get Frans to Japan!

story:
The Crisis

Most recent data describes a shocking gap in access to reading materials: “While the ratio of books to children in middle-income neighborhoods is approximately 13 books per child, the ratio in low-income neighborhoods is 1 book per 300 children.” In Houston, 240,000 children under 18 live in low-income neighborhoods. Of these 240,000 children, 72,000 read below grade-level--enough to fill Reliant Stadium.  By providing children with books they can take home and keep, First Book – Houston targets the only variable that correlates significantly with reading scores—the number of books in the home. 

Our Solution

First Book is an award-winning nonprofit organization which provides new books to children in need addressing one of the most important factors affecting literacy – access to books.  First Book’s network of local volunteer groups in over 180 communities nationwide harnesses the power of a massive grassroots network. 

Advisory Boards raise funds locally and select programs in their community as First Book grantees.  Grantees use the funds provided by First Book to select books from the First Book Marketplace, an online store of deeply discounted books.  New books chosen by program leaders working directly with children are incorporated into program lessons, and then given to the children to take home and keep.  First Book – Houston works with local programs such as Houston ISD, to reach children in need in Houston and provide them with free books and educational materials.  Our local volunteer Advisory Board has been working in Houston since 2012 and has distributed more than 5,000 books throughout.

 

How You Can Help

For every $2.00 that you donate, a child in need will receive a brand new book. 

Access to books is essential to reading development.  In middle income neighborhoods the ratio of books per child is 13 to 1, but in low-income neighborhoods, the ratio is 1 age-appropriate book for every 300 children. And shockingly, over 80 percent of childcare centers serving low-income children lack age-appropriate books and other print materials.  By providing children from low-income families with books they can take home and keep, First Book targets the only variable that correlates significantly with reading scores—the number of books in the home.

story:
Short Summary

We are a grassroots Nova Southeastern University MOT Class of 2015 student committee aimed to raise support and funding for a 3D Makerbot 2 printer and materials to fabricate Robohand mechanical device (hand prosthesis) prototypes for both research and distribution to children with amniotic band syndrome and finger amputees. 


We believe that the affordability and functionality of these hand devices can help children with underdeveloped hands (from amniotic band syndrome or other cause) reach developmental motor milestones and grow with a sense of inclusiveness and social acceptance. We'd also like to distribute these Robohands to individuals with injured, amputated, and/or underdeveloped hands (war veterans, amputees, etc) to help them return to engagement in meaningful activities (work, sport, art, etc.) while positively impacting their independence and self worth.

Please see the Robohand video at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WT3772yhr0o

We are currently working with Richard Van As, founder of Robohand and narrator of the video above. We are also in contact and supported by an occupational therapist that works with child amputees at Miami Children's Hospital.

We are currently constructing a proposal to our department chair for more funding if our initial pilot project is successful. This will increase the number of Robohands we're able to create and the amount of people we can help.

The Numbers:

  • A Makerbot 2 3D Printer costs $2,854:

http://store.makerbot.com/replicator2.html

  • A Robohand currently goes for $2,000
  • A comparable custom device not made by a 3D printer costs $47,000
  • This campaign is to fund our initial 3D printer and Robohand prototypes.
  • Any money left after creating our initial prototypes for our proposal will go directly to Robohand to fund these devices for people that need them but cannot afford them.

Who is this for:

  • Amniotic banding affects approximately 1 in 1,200 live births. It is also believed to be the cause of 178 in 10,000 miscarriages. Up to 50% of cases have other congenital anomalies including cleft lip, cleft palate, and clubfoot deformity. Hand and finger anomalies occur in up to 80%. 

http://fetus.ucsfmedicalcenter.org/amniotic/learn_more.asp

  • There are approximately 400,000 amputees in the U.S today, and 135,000 new amputees per year. The majority of upper extremity amputations are of the fingers.

http://dps.missouri.edu/resources/Handbook/amputation.pdf

We are currently:

  • Compiling research articles on evidence of how hand prostheses help children develop self-worth, social acceptance, and developmental motor skills.
  • Compiling research articles on how hand prostheses help finger amputees reintegrate into the workforce and society and return to engaging in meaningful activities (work, sport, art, etc.).
  • Researching grant writing forms and proposals
  • Pricing Makerbot 2 3D printers and cost of robohand materials vs current hand prosthetic options
  • Contacting and networking with hand therapists, engineers, businessmen, and prosthetists to build professional support for research
  • In contact and supported by Richard Van As, founder of Robohand and narrator of the video above.

We would like to:

  • Create a prototype Robohand and make a promotional video of one of us going through our day exhibiting all the things a Robohand can do
  • Make a proposal to our OT department chair for funding and resources to begin lab and clinical research on the efficacy of Robohands by October 30
  • Begin pilot research on the child development and rehabilitation effects of Robohand
  • Distribute Robohands to research participants with amniotic band syndrome and finger amputations free of charge
  • Within a couple years, present our findings to the American Occupational Therapy Association
  • Get as many of these Robohands to financially constrained children, war veterans, tradesmen, and anyone else we can both nationally and internationally
  • Change the world for the better

Your support will help us:

  • Fund Maketbot 2 printers and materials for creating Robohand prototypes
  • Show support for our pilot research to our department chair and the occupational therapy and healthcare community
  • Create and modify Robohand specifications for applications in many other hand and wrist conditions
  • Fabricate as many Robohand devices and get them to as many kids and amputees as possible
  • Any left over funding will go directly to Robohand to fund getting devices to people in need

The Impact:

The implications of increasing the efficacy and viability of Robohands are astronomical. We are highly motivated and passionate about making this happen. Within a few years, 3D printers will be consumer available, and the possibilities on fabricating hand devices and medical equipment are endless. The sooner research starts, the sooner it can be recognized and prescribed to those that need it. This can reach underdeveloped countries with limited resources. This can help day to day people return to their lives (work, sport, art, etc.) after finger amputations. This can give children born with underdeveloped hands a chance to grow and play with a sense of belonging and purpose. We want to do more than help people get hands; we want to help people live happier and more meaningful lives.

You can follow our "Give Yourself a Hand Project" Facebook group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/603764063007367/

Thank you for your time and support!

story:
About Culturs.guru

CULTURS global multicultural magazine celebrates the unique perspectives of Global Nomads, Third Culture Kids(TCKs), and ethnically- and culturally-blended people – those who are “culturally mobile.”  Visitors can enjoy lifestyle multimedia content, international news and the latest TCK research from unique perspectives that show a new-world order — a new normal that reflects the hidden diversity that’s increasingly becoming the hallmark of daily living around the globe. #LocallyMadeGloballyMinded

WHY WE'RE WORTH IT:

1.  Innovative - Culturs.guru is the first publication of its kind, with research, products, news and lifestyle information for this long-neglected population.

2.  Timely -  If you’ve noticed lately, multiculturalism, multi-racial people, and globalism are garnering a lot of attention. Even big brands see the trend, like Cheerios’ recent bi-racial family commercial or Coca Cola’s multilingual Superbowl Ad, “America the Beautiful.”

3. Charitable – Culturs.guru supports important organizations around the world, building awareness of issues and donating proceeds from the Culturs.guru marketplace to U.S. and global organizations.

Hidden Diversity Comes to Light --

Culturs.guru seeks to grow its already lively community. From student writers in our partnership with the Journalism Department at Colorado State University, to TCKs in our partnership with TCKid.com, to our Culturs Experts: award winning filmmakers and models in Europe and Asia, professionals and lifestyle experts in South America and Africa -- Culturs' writers, photographers, editors and videographers represent the diversity and uniqueness of spirit that flows through many who soon will understand what it means to be culturally mobile. We aim to create a place where our audience can feel they belong, find out more about themselves and create a community.

Local Meetups and Events -- During the year, Culturs will foster meetups at local locations around the globe, so our readers and viewers can experience each other in person, as well as virtually. This year, our new year party will be held in Kenya (or Austrailia), London, New York and Honolulu and live streamed on the web.

A truly new, new year -- Each year, Culturs.guru will hold a "rolling New Year," highlighting each time zone across the globe and celebrating new year in countries of that time zone in the web magazine and via live stream video online (as the new year rolls in for each time zone).  The two weeks leading to new year, a Culturs' team will visit a new global location to feature culture, tourism, food, people, must-see activities, customs etc. as a lead in to the "rolling New Year."  This year's global subject will be Kenya or Australia.

Culturs.guru tv -- Launching Sept. 1 is Culturs Television, offering lifestyle segments with our population--conversation roundtables, special events and interviews with Culturs Experts and International Celebrities.  Get ready!  This will be good...

CultursKids

So excited to bring on board 11-year-old Kameron McMillion with the column "Kam's Eye View"  -- global culture from a 'tween point of view!  Kam is ambassador to Singapore's "Save the Pandas," and already has demonstrated talent and acumen with amazing stories about culture and hidden diversity.  Launching on Culturs.guru in July!

What We Need & What You Get

We seek funds to send our Colorado State University student contributors to Kenya to cover our Rolling New Year! Help them achieve this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to garner professional video, photo, writing and editing skills and take part in a worldwide production that is simulcast and hosted in four countries.  Experience like this could launch their careers, and at the very least, create outstanding portfolios to present when they graduate.

Culturs also has a marketplace in the web magazine, and all proceeds from that market will support Culturs' so that the publication can continue to bring great content, free of charge, to this deserving audience and increase global awareness of this population. You can rest assured that every donation will further the cause and go to good use.  While reaching our funding goal will help us expand, any amount will go a long way to providing free, quality content to our readers, viewers and audience! The Marketplace also is where we help support deserving organizations in the U.S. and around the globe.  Check out our press release for more details.

The ImpactOur founder, Doni Luckutt, has an MBA and ran a successful global business for 15 years.  She has been a member of the media for more than two decades and plans to tap those skills to get the word out about this campaign and Culturs. Luckutt's Trinidadian and Costa Rican heritage make her ethnically- and culturally-blended, while her world travels make her a TCK, Military Brat, and Global Nomad. Taking her first international trip at age 2 months, Luckutt lived in 7 countries before adulthood and travel to many more.


Our team consists of seasoned photographers, videographers, writers, global experts and more, all of whom currently volunteer their time to create the Culturs product.  The entire team is committed and energized by this audience and the work we do.  We look forward to energizing the community as well!

Culturs' internal list, plus our media partnerships in international print, web, and television gives us a reach of multiple millions across the globe!  During this campaign, we will unveil these media partners! We strive to continue creating partnerships that help grow the readership and take this unique content to as many people as possible.

And!  We have so many exciting things in the works that will be announced throughout the campaign -- like our celebrity friends, and amazing, once-in-a-lifetime perks!  But rest assured, our contributors and community will be the first to know.  Think of it this way: Some of the world's most coveted events, people and occasions can now be part of your inner circle. And your contributions help us get there. #CantWaitToShare

Other Ways You Can Help

We'd love if everyone could donate, but getting the word out is a great help as well!  Use the Indiegogo social media links to easily send our information to five friends you think could help us reach our goal or forward to their friends.  Together, we can make this happen!

Check out our perks!  We have some cool gear, trips and celebrity perks still being solidified....check in often to see what's new!

Welcome to Culturs.guru.  Welcome HOME.
story_txt:
About Culturs.guru

CULTURS global multicultural magazine celebrates the unique perspectives of
Global Nomads, Third Culture Kids(TCKs), and ethnically- and culturally-blended
people – those who are “culturally mobile.” 
Visitors can enjoy lifestyle multimedia content, international news and the latest TCK research from unique perspectives that show a new-world order — a
new normal that reflects the hidden diversity that’s increasingly becoming the
hallmark of daily living around the globe. #LocallyMadeGloballyMindedWHY WE'RE WORTH IT:1. 
Innovative
- Culturs.guru is the first publication of its kind, with research, products,
news and lifestyle information for this long-neglected population.2. 
Timely
-  If you’ve noticed lately, multiculturalism,
multi-racial people, and globalism are garnering a lot of attention. Even
big brands see the trend, like Cheerios’ recent bi-racial family commercial or
Coca Cola’s multilingual Superbowl Ad, “America
the Beautiful.”3. Charitable – Culturs.guru supports important organizations around
the world, building awareness of issues and donating proceeds from the
Culturs.guru marketplace to U.S. and global organizations.Hidden Diversity Comes to Light -- Culturs.guru seeks to grow its already lively community. From student writers in our partnership with the Journalism Department at Colorado
State University, to TCKs in our partnership with TCKid.com, to our Culturs Experts: award winning filmmakers and models in Europe and Asia, professionals and lifestyle experts in South America and Africa --
Culturs' writers, photographers, editors and videographers represent the diversity and uniqueness of spirit that flows through
many who soon will understand what it means to be culturally mobile. We aim to create a place where our audience can feel they belong, find out more about themselves and create a community.Local Meetups and Events -- During the year, Culturs will foster meetups at local locations around the globe, so our readers and viewers can experience each other in person, as well as virtually. This year, our new year party will be held in Kenya (or Austrailia), London, New York and Honolulu and live streamed on the web.A truly new, new year -- Each year, Culturs.guru will hold a "rolling New Year," highlighting each 
time zone across the globe and celebrating new year in countries of 
that time zone in the web magazine and via live stream video online (as the new year rolls in for each time zone).  
The two weeks leading to new year, a Culturs' team will visit a new 
global location to feature culture, tourism, food, people, must-see activities, customs etc. as a 
lead in to the "rolling New Year."  This year's global subject will be 
Kenya or Australia.Culturs.guru tv -- Launching Sept. 1 is Culturs Television, offering lifestyle segments with our population--conversation roundtables, special events and interviews with Culturs Experts and International Celebrities.  Get ready!  This will be good...CultursKidsSo excited to bring on board 11-year-old Kameron McMillion with the column "Kam's Eye View"  -- global culture from a 'tween point of view!  Kam is ambassador to Singapore's "Save the Pandas," and already has demonstrated talent and acumen with amazing stories about culture and hidden diversity.  Launching on Culturs.guru in July!   What We Need & What You Get We seek funds to send our Colorado State University student contributors to Kenya to cover our Rolling New Year! Help them achieve this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to garner professional video, photo, writing and editing skills and take part in a worldwide production that is simulcast and hosted in four countries.  Experience like this could launch their careers, and at the very least, create outstanding portfolios to present when they graduate. Culturs also has a marketplace in the web magazine, and all proceeds from that market will support Culturs' so that the publication can continue to bring great content, free of charge, to this deserving audience and increase global awareness of this population. You can rest assured that every donation will further the cause and go to good use.  While reaching our funding goal will help us expand, any amount will go a long way to providing free, quality content to our readers, viewers and audience! The Marketplace also is where we help support deserving organizations in the U.S. and around the globe.  Check out our press release for more details.  The ImpactOur founder, Doni Luckutt, has an MBA and ran a successful global business for 15 years.  She has been a member of the media for more than two decades and plans to tap those skills to get the word out about this campaign and Culturs. We strive to continue creating partnerships that help grow the readership and take this unique content to as many people as possible. story:
Hello, I am Alex and I am a mother of four beautiful children .  I am currently in the next to last semester of my masters in Midwifery program. I have been a labor/delivery nurse for a number of years and decided I wanted to do more to help women - I wanted to BE with women during a transitional point in their life...so I started on this midwifery path 4 years ago.


I also suffer from RA (rheumatoid arthritis) and it has made life and work difficult to maintain.  Our income has suffered greatly.  Putting in 12 hour days and an hour drive each way has increased the severity of my RA symptoms.

We are in need of assistance to help with life expenses - heating, food, prescriptions, and gas in the car.

Any help that you can give is GREATLY appreciated.


Thank you for taking the time to read this and I hope you have a blessed day.


-Alexandra and Family :)

story:
My Health


Short Summary

So my health is pretty important to me and anyway I suppose I'm raising this money to help me along with it.

I am a woman with a trans history and I am rather privileged but I have over extended myself financially and my insurance doesn't seem to want to pay for a health claim of mine so I thought I would try fundraising the money, not to directly cover the surgery but to instead insure that in the future the surgery is covered for people in similar circumstances.

In addition my finances have been strained as I am currently off of work on Stress Leave.

My health is the most important thing to me and with your assistance I plan to get this covered for myself and in turn take some time in my future to ensure that others in my same situation never go through the same thing.  

It's important to note I'm actually not raising the money for surgery directly as I have already paid for it out of pocket.  Because I have paid for it out of pocket I do not have high enough savings to cover the retainer fee for the law firm I plan to hire.

All money raised will go to my legal representation in the course of an Ontario Human Rights Commission Complaint which was filed the week ending March 23rd 2014.

The Respondents as per the claim are OHIP, the CAMH GIC, and Sunlife Assurance Company of Canada.

Do you want to help support me in all this?  I think if you do you will be pleasantly surprised about how deeply I will commit myself to it and how I can make a difference.

I need $10,000 to cover the retainer fee for my legal representation (CAD).

I'm an artist so the perks of donating is original art work from myself and a chance to make a difference.

Also last but not least the grand prize is a date with me and my future boobs once I have recovered from surgery.

You can help by spreading the word even if you can't donate and helping me on an organizational level or donating your own skills as perks for people who donate.

Thank you for taking the time to read all this!

<3 Danielle

story:
My Classroom & Students

This is my 2nd year teaching Special Education at a Title I school in El Sobrante, California.  My 7th and 8th graders are eager to enter FIRST LEGO League's (FLL) robotic competition this year.  

FLL's theme this year is "Nature's Fury." My students will be given the opportunity to identify a community that could experience a natural disaster, identify a problem that happens when a natural disaster occurs, create an innovative solution that helps people prepare, stay safe, or rebuild, and share the problem and solution with others.  After conducting research, my students will work together as a team to build and program a robot to complete safety preparedness tasks!

To make this reality possible, we need your help to fund our project!

What We Need 

We need $800 to cover material costs for the competition.  Every bit counts!!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our campaign with friends and family!
  • Send my students notes of encouragement and support!

story:
My story

I am a 19 year old student from the Dominican Republic. I am currently attending university here.

Since I can remember, I have always liked history, travelling and I have been fascinated with the scandinavian way of living. This is why I decided to apply to a bachelor degree in history at a university in Norway. This country is by far my favourite place on earth and this is why I have decided to go there but there are some obstacles I have to pass before reaching my goal, and the economic obstacle is one.

I want to become a teacher in the field of history and social sciences. I would like to give something positive back to our society by becoming a qualified and good teacher. In Norway education is almost perfect so I can not think of any other place that could give me the chance to become what I want to be.  This campaign is very important for me as it can be a life changing opportunity and can give me the opportunity to get quality education, something I can not find in my own country, in order to become a qualified proffesional. I will be an amazing teacher!

What do I need and what will happen next?

WHERE WILL YOUR CONTRIBUTION GO?: The money I'll get from your donation will be exclusively used to cover all my expenses related to my studies in Norway. This means the money will go to my housing, food, transporation, books, clothing (as in clothing I really need such as winter clothing) and any other thing I have to pay in a period of 1 to 2 years.

Approximate budget (for five months):

Housing: 2000 USD

Food: 2000 USD

Books and supplies: 800 USD

Transportation: 500 USD

Other expenses: 1700 USD

Total = 7000 USD

As said before, this will only benefit me as I don't see how I can give you something back. The only thing I can give you back is my most sincere thank you and the feeling of ''I helped that guy to reach his dreams and become a qualified proffessional''. One thing I will give back is a good teacher to the society I will be established in. Thanks to you!

If I don't get enough money I wouldn't feel bad because I know there's people out there willing to help. The money I'll get will still be used to help my parents support me! I have also decided to donate 20% of the donations I recieve to any fundraising campaign, especially in the field of heatlh.

I am aware the amount requested is big just for one single person but this will be put in use for several months!


The impact

This will help me reach my dream of studying abroad in an awesome country and become a qualified proffessional in my favourite area: History!


Other ways you can help me

If you can't contribute it does not matters! You can still help me by sharing my story!

story:
Culture Relay 

Culture Relay’s mission is to create female leaders of tomorrow through a year long program that uses running to teach leaderships skills to high school girls.  We have partnered with schools across the world to create a virtual classroom. We prepare girls to run the world by teaching them how to set goals, overcome challenges, develop grit, and get results. Training together to run a half marathon is the first step. Once they cross the finish line, they exercise all they have learned on local projects approved by their business mentor. 

Our Pilot program participants shared their thoughts:

"This organization had a constant foundation of empowering each participant to set high goals and work in a systematic and rational way to reach them” – Sarah, 15

“I learned about the Jordanian culture from my buddy. I found the cultural differences very interesting. It amazes me that people live so differently there. I think I have become more open, and my communication skills have improved”- Kendall, 15

“I liked learning about how to be healthier and more active ”- Emily, 15

                                                                     

                         

Some of our community service projects include:

  • Financial education services (for adults and kids) 

  • Health and wellness (fruit/vegetable community garden, nutrition education classes, drugs and alcohol prevention) 

We are preparing to  launch our second program—this time connecting Kenya to the US because of strong ties between the education systems in each place.

Several key pieces of research shape this mission:
  • Girls are less active than boys, particularly in high school. 62% of girls were not physically active on 5 or more days versus 42% of boys (CDC.gov)

  • Sports participation is proven to provide a behavioral compass to teens and improve self-esteem. Compared to non-athlete peers, female high school athletes are less likely to be sexually active, to use drugs, and to suffer from depression (Women's Sports Foundation, 2004)

  • Life skills are crucial for teens to learn in order to become independent adults. Budgets and money, developing people skills, and managing time are all important skills not formally taught (Washington Post, 2012)

  • Civic engagement starts early, and volunteerism is needed to connect to the larger world. Globally competent students act in creative and ethical ways to contribute to improvement locally, regionally, or globally and assess the impact of the actions taken (Mansilla & Jackson, 2011)

     How You Can Help

    In order to help our Kenyan and American girls connect, train, learn, grow, and give back, we need to raise funds that will kickstart this program. We are asking for  $12,906— a memorable amount that  creates a mental bridge of the real distance between our school in Kenya and the US. 
    By donating to Culture Relay, you have a direct impact on our participants in helping them achieve their full and unique potential. We are a volunteer-only organization, which means your donations go straight to the Culture Relay program itself. For a donation of $1,000, you can support a girl through an entire year of the program, including start up funds for her local community service project. Now that's impactful!
    Your generous gift will be spent on 4 things:
    • formalizing our curriculum
    • conducting research on our outcomes, and
    • seed funding girl-led community service projects
    • expanding our program to other US states and countries

                           


    How we evaluate success 

    Working with the associate Dean for Research at University of Alabama, we have created a pre and post program evaluation to understand the efficacy of Culture Relay's impact.  This test consists of 30 questions regarding self confidence, body image, exercise, nutrition, and leaderships skills.

    Along with our pre/post program evaluation, we also measure 4 outputs:

    • # of Graduating Participants

    • # of participants who complete the race

    • # of steps/strides in training

    • # of incubator projects


      Beyond Donations- Other Ways You Can Help

      We know our ask is big...but we also know it is achievable with your support! After you've contributed, please spread the word! Connect with us on Instagram, Facebook, and Twitter pages.

story:
"The idea of our project with Guido is to preserve the transmission of music as a universal heritage and give opportunities to local artists. This will be the first ever studio built in our exiled Tibetan community. Through music we transcend barriers of culture, politics, language and beliefs."

Jigme Tenzin, Exile brothers, Dharamsala, India 

My name is Guido Nisenson, I am a sound engineer and music producer from Argentina living in Spain and I have been working  all over the world recording musicians for more than 30 years. I met with Jigme and the Exile Brothers in February 2014 in Dharamsala, India, through my friends at Playing For Change who had met and recorded them a few years earlier. Since the moment I met with Jigme and his community, I realized that their main need was related to what I had been doing all my life: recording and producing music.

Guido has worked with Playing For Change on several occasions as both a sound engineer for the PFC Band shows and a recording engineer, and he has traveled with the crew to places such as Morocco, India, Spain, Brazil and the USA.

The goal of this new project is to create a community recording studio in Dharamsala, teach essential skills on how to produce recordings and how to manage the studio and equipments, setting up the foundation of a sustainable educational music program.

By contributing to this project you will help preserve and transmit a universal heritage and give a voice to a stateless community in need of inspiration and new ways to express its cultural identity through music.


 In February 2014, I went to Dharamsala to meet with the Exile Brothers and study the possibility of creating this recording studio and music program in the area of McLeod Ganj (Dharamsala). During my two-month stay I initiated the training of local musicians to the art of recording and mixing and recorded 2 albums with them.

It is now time to return and take this collaboration to the next level by setting up the recording studio with them and continuing to train them on using the equipments, producing their own music, recording local artists and encouraging them to share their musical talent in the community.

---

BUDGET: 8000 USD

83,75 % of the budget of the project will be allocated to buy recording equipments, the rest will cover the flight to Delhi.

I already managed to get 2 computers donated, a basic audio interface and a few pieces of recording equipment through my networks. The idea is to complete this initial list with new equipment to be able to create a simple but effective recording studio.

Here is the detail of remaining equipment needed:

Equipments.

Interface

Digidesign 003

500€

Pro Tools software

Pro Tools 11

500€

Headphones

6 x AKG K-121 Studio

408€ (68€/u)

Speakers

2 x Yamaha HS 5

318€ (159€/u)

Headphones

splitter

Sonifex Redbox RB-DA6

442€

Mics

6 x Shure 57

654€ (109€/u)

4 x Shure 58

436€ (109€/u)

1 x Shure B 52

177€

2 x AKG Perception 220

310€ (155€/u)

2 x AudioTech. AT 2035

332€ (166€/u)

Misc

Cables, stands, anti pop...  (purchased locally)

700€

Acoustic treatment

Auralex Acoustic Roominators Alpha-DST Burgundy (purchased locally)

448€

Hard-drives

Lacie 3TB USB 3.0

160€

Total

5385€=6700 $(dollars)


-Flight from Madrid to Delhi: 1300 USD (16,25% of total)

I will personally take care of my accommodation and expenses there in order to keep the budget as reasonable as possible.

Hosting a music program at the studio

One of the goals of the project on a mid term perspective is to convert the studio into a place dedicated to the transmission of musical knowledge by utilizing our team not only to record other artists but also to teach music to young kids. 

The recording classes will be geared toward youth between 15 and 25 years old and the music classes will be geared toward children over 8 years old. Music classes will take place 10 hours per week and will focus on teaching traditional instruments as well as music history.

The operating budget will be around 100 USD/ month to keep the studio active and provide music education to local youth.

Who's teaching:

Jigme and Tenzin Chodup (traditional master instrumentist) from TIPA (Tibetan Institute Perfoming Arts). More people will be identified during Guido’s travel to set the project. 

Sustaining the operating budget:

The recording equipment and training represent an investment that will create opportunities to help sustain the project. 

The will be cultural exchanges with Western musicians who can come to learn traditional Tibetan music and contribute financially to the project in exchange for music lessons. Three-week workshops can be organized 2 to 3 times a year to help sustain the project. The duration of the workshop will be around 3 weeks. Accommodation will be provided in the area for participants, music instruction and recording.

During the year, the studio will also be utilized to produce recordings whose sales will help finance the operating costs. Tibetan and indian music have a significant audience in western countries, thanks to the expansion of yoga centers all over the world, and some of the recordings done at the studio could directly target this potential market.

The Place:

We already have a place of 18x8 meters in McLeod Ganj in Baghsu Road. We will work on soundproofing the studio to leave it as clean and unobstructed as possible, and take advantage of the space so that we can record several musicians at once, in order to preserve the real feel of this art form.

Partners:

- Tibetan Children Village :This group will play an essential role in the coordination of the  music and recording classes at the studio.

-TIPA (Tibetan Institute Perfoming Arts): We are going to create cultural exchanges will this cultural center that has years of experience and a large network of musicians in the area.

-Playing For Change:

Playing for Change met with the Exile Brothers a few years ago and sparked my desire to create something with them. 

- Andrés Calamaro (Argentinian musician)

-"Micky" from Mexican Band Molotov.

-Control Machete members

-Chilean musician Joe Vasconcellos
story_txt:
"The idea of our project with Guido is to preserve the transmission of music as a universal heritage and give opportunities to local artists. This will be the first ever studio built in our exiled Tibetan community. Through music we transcend barriers of culture, politics, language and beliefs."Jigme Tenzin, Exile brothers, Dharamsala, India 
My name is Guido Nisenson, I am a sound engineer and music producer from Argentina living in Spain and I have been working  all over the world recording musicians for more than 30 years. I met with Jigme and the Exile Brothers in February 2014 in Dharamsala, India, through my friends at Playing For Change who had met and recorded them a few years earlier. Since the moment I met with Jigme and his community, I realized that their main need was related to what I had been doing all my life: recording and producing music.Guido has worked with Playing For Change on several occasions as both a sound engineer for the PFC Band shows and a recording engineer, and he has traveled with the crew to places such as Morocco, India, Spain, Brazil and the USA.
The goal of this new project is to create a community recording studio in Dharamsala, teach essential skills on how to produce recordings and how to manage the studio and equipments, setting up the foundation of a sustainable educational music program.By contributing to this project you will help preserve and transmit a universal heritage and give a voice to a stateless community in need of inspiration and new ways to express its cultural identity through music. In February
2014, I went to Dharamsala to meet with the Exile Brothers and study the possibility
of creating this recording studio and music program in the area of McLeod Ganj (Dharamsala). During my two-month stay I initiated the training of local musicians to the art of recording and mixing and recorded 2 albums with them.It is now time to return and take this collaboration to the next level by setting up the recording studio with them and continuing to train them on using the equipments, producing their own music, recording local artists and encouraging them to share their musical talent in the community.---BUDGET: 8000 USD83,75 % of the budget of the project will be allocated to buy recording equipments, the rest will cover the flight to Delhi.I already managed to get 2 computers donated, a basic audio interface and a few pieces of recording equipment through my networks. The idea is to complete this initial list with new equipment to be able to create a simple but effective recording studio.Here is the detail of remaining equipment needed:Equipments.

-Flight from Madrid to Delhi: 1300 USD (16,25% of total)
I will personally take care of my accommodation and expenses there in order to keep the budget as reasonable as possible.Hosting a music program at the studioOne of the goals of the project on a mid term perspective is to convert the studio into a place dedicated to the transmission of musical knowledge by utilizing our team not only to record other artists but also to teach music to young kids. 
The recording classes will be geared toward youth between 15 and
25 years old and the music classes will be geared toward children over 8 years old. Music classes will take place 10 hours per
week and will focus on teaching traditional instruments as well as music
history.
The operating budget will be around 100 USD/ month to keep the studio
active and provide music education to local youth.Who's teaching:Jigme and Tenzin Chodup (traditional master instrumentist) from TIPA (Tibetan Institute Perfoming Arts). More
people will be identified during Guido’s travel to set the project. 

Sustaining
the operating budget:The recording equipment and training represent an investment that will create opportunities to help sustain the project. 
The will be cultural exchanges with Western musicians who can come to learn traditional
Tibetan music and contribute financially to the project in exchange for music lessons. Three-week workshops can be organized 2 to 3 times a year to help
sustain the project. The duration of the workshop will be around 3 weeks. Accommodation
will be provided in the area for participants, music instruction and recording.
During the year, the studio will also be utilized to produce recordings
whose sales will help finance the operating costs. Tibetan and indian music
have a significant audience in western countries, thanks to the expansion of yoga
centers all over the world, and some of the recordings done at the studio could
directly target this potential market.

The Place:

We already have a
place of 18x8 meters in McLeod Ganj in Baghsu Road. We will work on soundproofing the studio to leave it as clean and unobstructed as possible, and take advantage of the space so that we can record several musicians at once, in order to preserve the real feel of this art form.
Partners:
- Tibetan Children Village :This group will play an essential role in the coordination of the  music and recording classes
at the studio.
-TIPA (Tibetan
Institute Perfoming Arts): We are going to create cultural exchanges will this cultural center that has years of experience and a large network of musicians in the area.


-Playing For Change:Playing for Change met with the Exile Brothers a few years ago and sparked my desire to create something with them. - Andrés Calamaro (Argentinian musician)-"Micky" from Mexican Band Molotov.-Control Machete members
